reviewText:
Many moons ago in 2003 I stumbled upon a trailer for a game called S.T.A.L.K.E.R. Oblivion Lost https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DbGlgbw9J18 Needless to say after watching that I quickly became obsessed with this game. Searching high and low for every bit of info I could get my eyes on, The GSC forums became my 2nd home while I awaited its arrival.

I remember at the time I was playing Elder Scrolls III: Morrowind, With it I fell in love with non-linear open world 1st/3rd person games with RPG elements and how much I could get immersed in virtual worlds. I am all for fantasy settings don't get me wrong, but there is nothing more terrifying than reality. (With a spin of fiction of course, alternate reality if you will) The abandoned urban/industrial locations in S.T.A.L.K.E.R. were more my cup of tea. That in itself made me very excited to play it. I couldn't wait to get lost in its world.

While I waited though I researched about the Nuclear disaster at Chernobyl in April 1986, it was mixed emotions for me. I was sad/amazed/intrigued. Sad for all of those people who lost their lives because of this. Nothing but respect for the liquidators and anyone involved in the initial cleanup. Those people are heroes and deserve nothing less. Amazed that this game had some real history in its background story. Even if it is incredibly embellished (mutants, anomalies, artifacts etc etc.), you have to admit it makes for an interesting premise to a story. Finally, Intrigued on what these game developers had in store for the players to experience, without making a mockery of those who had lost their lives in this tragedy. The game also borrows elements from Roadside Picnic" by Boris and Arkady Strugatsky and the 1979  Andrei Tarkovsky film "Stalker". If you haven't heard or checked them out yet
date: they are most definitely worth it. Masterpieces in their own right.\n\nWell turns out it was a long wait lol

GSC Game World regardless of all the missing features still delivered a good game and it was well received by critics as well.\n\nThe game at release had performance issues and bugs that required some patching. Once that happened it was clear that S.T.A.L.K.E.R. - Shadow of Chernobyl was a game ahead of its time. In a league all its own and a true gem in the PC gaming world. The atmosphere takes front row seat in this game it is almost like another character in the game. Such believable atmosphere it is downright amazing

reviewText:
9/10

S.T.A.L.K.E.R. is by far one of the best games I have played. No matter what happens, I am still able to come back to it thanks to the amount of quality mods, challenges, and the whole random element to the games that keeps the games fresh. The story is also very good considering how open it is for people to make their own stories within the STALKER universe be it the shape in a mod or even fan fiction. The gameplay is almost always intense because enemies can easily kill you if you're playing the proper difficulty which I will get to at the end. The graphics aren't amazing except for the lighting which, for some reason, has the ability to compete with most modern games.

The only reasons why I took off one point is because there are plenty of bugs and the multiplayer just seems like a useless feature shoved in at the last minute. The bugs for the most part can be fixed with a community patch known as the Zone Reclamation Project or ZRP. In my opinion, ZRP isn't even necessary because it is very possible to get through the game without it. Whatever you do, do NOT listen to people who suggest playing with mods like Complete or anything that isn't ZRP. As for multiplayer, there isn't really much to deal with multiplayer other than to simply not play it. The singleplayer experience is simply the best part about this game.

I feel I should also say that this game is not for everyone as it can be pretty difficult at times. However, being a person who has gotten around five people into the series by gifting the game to them, I feel that anyone interested should pickup this game and just try it.

To have the best experience, you should play on Master difficulty as this is the way the game was meant to be played. Every other difficulty will ruin your immersion and will end up with you becoming overpowered right at the beginning of the game. If you are going to play through the whole STALKER Series, start with Shadow of Chernobyl, then Clear Sky, and then end with Call of Pripyat.

And of course as said above, don't use mods on your first playthrough unless it is ZRP.

reviewText:
Get the community patch which upgrades graphics, enables quicker keys to save, breakable lights fixtures and more! Takes the game from good to great! STALKER is my favorite gaming style! (I got the file patch from gamefront. Its 703.1MB and an exe.
http://www.gamefront.com/files/16359911/STALKER_Complete_2009_# )

Sneak around and attempt to take out any force with stealth attacks. The more silent you are, the more deadly you become. When you kill an enemy, pick their body up and hide it. Enemies see only whats in their vision, and while an enemy is in-sight they appear on your mini-map. If you don't crouch, they will hear you even easier! Turn on night vision and pull out your silenced weapon to become the ultimate STALKER! (still challenging!)

Each NPC has a unique name, and they will remember if they like you. They can die from enemies too, though. The killed NPCs are replaced with half as many fresh new NPCs, most of the time, which helps the game still feel alive, and progresses. If you shoot your friend once, they will forgive you. If you shoot them twice, then its war...

There are different groups/factions. Military, Bandits, Loners, Duty, Freedom, etc. Everything is at war. If you pis-off the Military, they will attack your base. If you don't ball-up, they will all die. Game changing! Although, you can save anytime you want. Which makes winning a serious battle, actually possible. Making you the most badass in the zone! Although, no one truly knows how cool you are, due to saves! ;D  (I wish there was a video replay, where it shows you how [through saving] your character is elite.)

Mutated animals run around constantly. Sometimes you can take a souvenier from them. The types of mutated creatures become really sneaky and different than you can imagine. They will solo attack armed soldier squads too. Sometimes wiping them out. You get no rewards for helping NPC communities survive, but it is rewarding to know you just saved a friendly base.

Better equipment comes much faster from helping NPCs with a task. But you will probably gain access to much of the same guns much later on, from fallen enemies, except armor never drops from enemies. Bullets fall with gravity. You can watch a bullet fall towards a distant target. If you choose to use a sniper weapon, you will have to adjust your manual aim to compensate for this new thing called gravity. Also, the distance between you and your target feels real!

What else... there are... artifacts, which give bonuses. They are supposed to be found in anomalies, which are dangerous ghost like traps. If you hear your radiation meter going off, throw a metal bolt by pressing 6, to see if you are about to get zapped by stepping on a trap. Also, if you hear radiation, you are probably getting pummeled with radiation poisoning. Might want to step back. Suit up to get less exposure! (This seems bigger in the game Pripyat.)

Lastly, the atmosphere is really in depth. Everyone speaks with a Russian accent, and when the wind blows the bushes wave. Day/Night cycles and eating let you feel like you are really camping in the zone. Its cold and a loner's friend.

reviewText:
I was recently introduced to the S.T.AL.K.E.R. universe through Shadow of Chernobyl. I was won over by this, it has so much going for it. A FPS sandbox game set in the Zone, a secret scientific facility with mysterious environmental anomalies in the ruins of Chernobyl. You are a Stalker, one of the many rogues who make a living by scavenging the ruins and seeking valuable rocks.

The environment is challenging, the array of weapons and other items is huge, great missions, great gameplay (stealth, economy, range and style of movement), plenty of mystery. I like that the gameplay continues while you rummage through your inventory. I really appreciated being immersed in a cultural environment that was not the usual Hollywood inspired rubbish - in this world you are a person with no history, trying to figure out your past against a Ukrainian-flavoured backdrop amongst hardened and macho men. This has a lot of blokey appeal.

This is one of the best dilapo porn games ever, picturesque and epic. Whenever I play a game that is based on a real-world location, I'm usually disappointed, but the Chernobyl Power Station map was one of the most enjoyable I have ever encountered, and not just for its epic representation of the location. This game is as close to perfection as a game can get.

I highly endorse this and Call of Pripyat - weeks of fun, and I can't wait to check out Clear Skies.

reviewText:
A Stalker is someone who ventures into the ecological disaster zone created by the fictional second explosion of the Chenobryl Nuclear Power Plant to recover artifacts that defy the laws of physics. I won't go into further details of the game, as I the mysteriousness of The Zone, and how to survive there are the most endearing features of the game.
It took me a long, long time to fall in love with S.T.A.L.K.E.R. I first booted this game up on release day, and my good 'ol Athlon64X2 choked on it. Performance won't be a problem in this day and age, but the X-ray engine's poor optimization was killer back in '07, and the fact that the patches would erase your save game only added insult to injury (again, this won't affect the gamers of today). After I had finally tweaked the game into a playable state, I found an intriguing title with a fantastic premise, and a living, breathing world overflowing with atmosphere. However, exploring The Zone wasn't the beautiful experience that it should have been. The place was crawling with bugs, glitches and anomalies (and not just kind you are supposed to be exploring there!) The shooting physics were far from consistent, the translations were poor, and the game would still crawl along at a snail's pace. There is still much to love about the game, but playing through on vanilla left me feeling that the title just didn't live up to all that it could have been.
That all changed with I discovered the heavy modding scene for the series. I recommend reading up on the various fan overhauls for Stalker, and installing one before you even first step foot in The Zone. There are many to choose from, such as Complete 2009, Misery, or my personal favorite, Lurk. After playing through the game with fan enhancements, I found myself beyond taken by this title's bleak wonders. I would go as far as saying that Stalker with the Lurk mod is my favorite first person shooter experience of all time. I found myself so infatuated by the Zone and her mysteries, that I read  and enjoyed the book ('Roadside Picnic,' Arkady and Boris Strugatsky, 1971) and  watched and adored the film ('Stalker', by Andrei Tarkovsky, 1979). I also researched the fascinating tragedy of the real life Chernobyl disaster of 1986.
In conclusion, if you are a patient gamer who fancies a real challenge and getting lost in a bleak world in a devastated Ukrane, I simply can't recommend a modded version of S.T.A.L.K.E.R enough.
Get out of here, Stalker.

100 Rads out of Ten

reviewText:
Yes the game is plagued by bugs, but gaze over them (or just install a simple mod fix) and what you‚Äôll find is an FPS with RPG and horror elements that evokes feelings that you‚Äôve possibly never experienced before. It perfectly captures the overwhelming mood of a decrepit world without getting repetitive or monotonous.

It captivates you, inundates you with a constant wave of ambience and atmosphere, creating an illusion of desolation. The realistic gameplay and sound effects coupled with the brilliant soundtrack and periodic spine tingling bellows from mutated monster(lings) in the distance helps forge this.

So despite being armed to the teeth with lead, gunpowder, rations and a generous light source it does what most (survival) horror games fail to do. It‚Äôs a preview of emptiness and loneliness. It makes you hesitate. Permit yourself temporary freedom and succumb to misery and mystery in the dense expanse known as The Zone.

Recommended mods:
-Autumn Aurora 2: Necessary tweaks and amplifications of what makes the game great while also keeping your experience as vanilla as possible.
-Zone Reclamation Project: All your technical issues fixed with one simple mod.

Additional recommendations:

reviewText:
NOTE: As I am reviewing the original product, and not various third-party mods, this review is based on a vanilla playthrough. Please keep that in mind, thank you.

+ Functional, user-friendly navigation and quest-mapping device
+ Artifacts add slight RPG-like stat combinations
+ Vast, detailed environments
+ Very, very strong sense of atmosphere pervading throughout
+ Boasts a large and active modding community (many mods do well to address some of the game's various pitfalls)
+ Equipment and weight limitations do much to force the optimization of one's gear, and make one choose what to discard and what to keep; this leaves the player feeling both challenged and rewarded as they acclimate to the concept
+ Ambient sounds are absolutely fantastic, and keep the player consistently unsettled
+ Weapon degredation adds to the challenge, and makes one keep an eye on their equipment
+ Manner of interaction with various game-world NPCs is largely determined by the player's actions throughout the adventure
+ The game's world and atmosphere compliments an intriguing plot; the story, itself, rewards inquisitiveness
+ Moderate variation in firearms
+ Absolute plethora of side-missions

- No fast-travel; this likely will not bother the realists out there, but I felt that there could have been a comfortable middle-ground implemented that would have kept everyone happy
- Lots and lots of bugs, some of which are quite problematic (again, most of these can be remedied via the modding community)
- Largely flat and uninspired voice-acting
- Malleable NPC relationships notwithstanding, the story is fairly (although not completely) linear
- No autosave function (except when entering new areas, but the environments are mostly sprawling areas, making this insufficient); massively frustrating when you die 45 minutes into a new area and forget to manually save, forcing you to take significant steps back in progress (although I believe there is a mod available to remedy this)

If you enjoyed this review, please follow my curator page. Also, feel free to join my group, LockeProposal's Big Day Out for discussion and announcements. Thanks for reading!

reviewText:
I‚Äôm not here to suggest you into buying it. After browsing many reviews both there and on the Metacritic, I see STALKER as a moving train. You‚Äôre either hopped on it, or not.

STALKER is not your usual big entertaining AAA-title, like Crysis or Call of Duty. It is more like living Monument. For my point of view, it is even bigger than Halo franchise.  Maybe bigger than Moby ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• (the Whale). And with strong Russian accent. I‚Äôm not saying that only Russian-speakers can understand this scenery, but you really have to have somewhat specific system of values and behavioural pattern, to get in tune with that game. And what pattern it could be?

Let me tell you where this game takes roots. It will be much better, than usual pro/contra stuff.

Okay, first, there was a book. It was written by Strugatsky brothers and called ‚ÄúRoadside Picnic‚Äù. In there was painted our world after a brief impact with extraterrestrial civilization. Those aliens wasn't contacted with people, they just used our planet as a campsite, and then disappeared in the space, while left some garbage at their leisure. The book‚Äôs story tells about some scientist who is researching that impact by studying strange alien artifacts, which can be recovered from abnormal zones aliens left behind. Due to its completely alien nature, the most of those ‚Äúcampsite‚Äù zones are extremely dangerous. Just like an oil puddle for ants.

After filming that scenario, directed by Andrei Tarkovsky, it turns out that the most natural and the most alive-looking character is not a day-dreaming scientist, wishing to make the world a better place. No, the main character of the movie was a simple guy, who dwelled the Zone by his instincts, intuition and luck, just for make a living for another day. The Stalker.

No, that‚Äôs not the end of the history lesson. After that movie, Chernobyl catastrophe happened. It was really far from the resemblance with the ‚ÄúRoadside Picnic‚Äù events, but, after all impersonal cruelty that striked the territory around Chernobyl area, a big circle of the deadland was created, which fitted to the anomaly zone by its size and tragic background.

And after that tragedy, there was a Soviet Union crush, which created so-called ‚Äúroaming 90‚Äôs‚Äù. Ex-Soviet people, left in the dark age with squashed moral principles, which kept them together all soviet years, started a struggle of survival on the ruins of former life. It was then when bandits were ruled every activity, promising some outcome, preferably the fastest and dirtiest way possible.

Finally, in the new millennia the governments of the former Union finally take some power back in their hands, so there was a time of peace in the 00‚Äôs in the Ukraine. Some talented people gather there and created a very powerful (yet not too stable) engine, and they blended Strugatsky, Tarkovsky, roaming 90‚Äôs under the shadow of Chernobyl zone‚Ä¶

So, here you are: a simple man, who tries to get by and live another day, yet must adapt and survive in the hostile terrain. You hunt vile creatures, explore and getting used to the location, where every 10 straight steps leading you to another death trap. You collect some strange artifacts, survive encounters with bandits and hostile military forces, you helping some random and generic friendly stalkers (and even getting some help in return). And after some time, you feel yourself like at home there‚Ä¶

Just like a soldier in his beloved trenches. Or a hunter in the wilderness, alone among wolves and bears. That‚Äôs a pattern of behaviour I was talking before. You‚Äôre not a hero in the shining armor, saving the world there. You just a survivalist, who‚Äôs getting stronger the harder fate trying to bend him. Without hope in government, in global order and justice, in helping hand from the Heaven‚Ä¶ just to live another day.

I know what not everybody could be like this. But Stalker game is giving so alive, so thrilling modus operandi that I know many people who played only in this videogame in the whole life.

Inexpressible in words, an unforgettable experience. Suspence. To kill or to be killed?

Okay, enough with pathos. As a game, STALKER obviously has flaws. Frequent engine crushes, questionable game features like constant respawn of enemies, narrow ravine between locations‚Ä¶

But all this pales, when I remember how many time (even before Steam) I‚Äôve spent there.
So that game takes a mark 10/10 from me, for being like no other. A quintessence of part of my life.

This game is an atmospheric and spooky game that takes place in an alternate universe after the chernobyl incident. In this universe, the chernobyl incident created an ever expanding zone which produces deadly anomalies and horrifying creatures whose prey consist of you.

You play as a STALKER, which basically is just a person who traverses the zone, who has suffered from some sort of amnesia. You only have one clear goal which is noted on your PDA: Kill Strelok.
Who strelok is or why you need to kill him is unknown, but you pursue this goal in hopes of finding out why you are trying kill him and what happened to you.

The game starts you in a small village with a simple goal of assisting nearby mecenaries in raiding a bandit camp, in hopes of retrieving a prisoner and a thumbdrive.

It sets the tone of the game very well. You can choose to experience the more stealthy lethal approach or the loud and proud route by talking to the head merc and choosing either option.

You get a quick feel for the tense gunplay (which I significantly recommend playing on max difficulty, it increases lethality for both sides during fights) and how the AI acts.

The game in essence is great. Sorry if the review isnt in depth, but the game is rock solid 10/10.
Though if you buy it know that you are supporting a person who practically tortured the dev team (who recieve no money from your purchase) and made them work in inhumane conditions.
No matter what way you choose to get it, this game is worth your time.

reviewText:
Stalker is a series that is somehow both ahead of its time and dated simultaneously.

Graphically the game isn't, and never was, the hottest thing on the market. However, the world that they dev. team have created is one of the most genuinely sinister and oppressive that I have ever experienced in a game. The creatures are disturbing and dangerous, and the lighting (particularly in the darkness) effectively creates a creeping, relentless tension. The moment in the tunnels when you look back and see the silhouette of the Controller emerge for the first time (seasoned players will know what I mean) is one of the most unnerving experiences I can recall having.

Like all the games in the series, Stalker doesn't coddle its players. Starting the game is quite brutal as it can take a new player some time to come to grips to the realism of the gunplay and the initially unforgiving difficulty of the enemies. The bullet physics are realistic in that your weapons aren't perfectly accurate, nor are they entirely reliable, and misfires can be common with weapons of a low condition, so you must use your brain and know your weapons and their limitations before initiating a firefight. In saying that, the game rewards the player by lightening the load as you progress and get better weapons and armour, and by the mid-point the difficulty can lessen considerably.

The sound is here and there in terms of quality, with the voice acting being average and flat a lot of the time, however, the atmospheric sound, weapon sounds, and THAT droning voice towards the end (seasoned players will understand), really plant a disturbing and terrifying chill in your spine the whole way through. Voice acting aside, the sound in these games are one of my favourite parts.

Stalker: SoC is a game I keep coming back to replay again and again, not in the least because of the quality of the mods out there. In saying that, the world that the devs have created and the emotions that that world inspires in me remains with me for long after every play session, and I think that, once one gets past the initial hurdles that the game places in front of you, this is one of the best post-apocalyptic games I've ever played. I feel that, whereas classics like Bioshock (for a random example) are fantastic games that appeal to everyone, cult classics are fantastic games that are an acquired taste. This is very much, in my mind, the absolute definition of cult classic. I highly recommend it (with a good mod like COMPLETE if you wish to smooth the creases out) to anyone looking for a deep, memorable and unsettling FPS experience.

reviewText:
I used to hate this game, really I did.

But I decided to give it another chance, and, I motherfudging love this game.


Can't beleive I used to hate this game to be honest, I just love how the mechanics work and the general gameplay is enjoyable.

The general disaproval of my original review (that was negative, bashing the game for the wrong reasons) persuaded me to give it another go, and I'm glad I did.
____________________________________________________________
Pros:

Cheeki Breeki.

Great combat.

Good ladder physics (I hate using ladders in the normal valve game, I'll slip and fall down to my death, or get gravely injured 9 times out of ten, but I never got screwed over by a ladder in this game before.)

Fantastic weapons.

Decent graphics.

Cool storyline (I originally thought it was boring, but at the time I never really got too involved in the storyline in the first place, you need to actually be invested in the tale itself, to be willing to experience it, in order to enjoy the story.)

Voiceacting is usually good, there are a few lines that are cheesy and a little underdone, but it's overall enjoyable.

Clothing and armor systems are very well made, the fact that you have to scavenge and trade for armors or be naked against the vicious wastelands just adds to the tension, which I will get to later.

Challenge: this was originally something I hated about the game, but I realised that living in a nuclear infested wasteland, in the middle of Northern Ukraine wouldn't be so easy. And it isn't.

Tension: I constantly find myself with my face glued to the screen, focusing on capturing a bandits' base, or clearing a military site from all inhabitants. The general suspence of the story and action gives a good vibe and leaves you wanting more.

Food mechanics: Usually games have an out of place or annoying way to tell you that you are litterally dying of malnutrition. Beeping, etc. There would normally be a huge bar or meter that takes up 50% of your hud and just sits there ticking away, dangling over your head.
While SoC likes to just display a tiny window telling you to eat. And when you eat, it goes away. Simple.

Scare Factor: I originally disliked the scare factor and claimed it wasn't scary at all, but
that was before I got into the underground levels. My seat has the urination of 7+ underground levels soaked into it.

First impression: First time I played this game I just looked at the begining cutscene, uninterested, unhyped.
I didn't even pay attention to it, I just critisized and gawked at the old graphics and continued on my marry little way.
But I never analyzed it for what it was, and now that I have I give it a good rating.

____________________________________________________________
Cons:

Questionable physics engine, Props, corpses and objects will slide and bump around sometimes, breaking immersion and generaly being buggy.

Silly and dumb AI. Usually I'll find bandits or military personel, mutants, friendlies, etc. Staring at walls, shooting ceilings, crouching for no good reason. Sometimes I'll see them killing themselves or other friends really for no actual reason, either. Other times they'll be shouting and screaming while crouched in a corner. The AI really act strange during combat, even not in combat as well.

Enemies, including mutants, will sometimes be in the middle of attacking me and suddenly not care, strolling in the other direction like nothing happened, in their normal voices and walking as if in a passive enviroment. Even during heated gunfights with other npcs, there will always be at least one guy strolling around like there arent grenades and bullets flying past his head.

One time. I started killing a few bandits near a fire, and as I offed them, the remaining 4 started shouting combat lines, shooting at me, flinching from gunfire, all behaving normally during a gunfight, as they should. Suddenly, they hostler their guns, turn around, and sit near the fire, singing, laughing, playing instruments, drinking vodka, eating sausages, talking to eachother and joking.
While I had just killed their entire squad in front of them

I proceeded to jump in front of them and they continued and even made eye contact with me, I shot one of them in the foot, ran in circles around them and they still never moved an inch. I got fed up and threw a grenade at one of them. They still continued to act idly as they shouted their grenade lines, still sitting down, exploded and died.

____________________________________________________________
This is where the Review ends, my conclusion as that this is an overall great game, a strong

9.3/10

reviewText:
Hundreds of hours invested in this on the disc version purchased many moons ago. STALKER is a bleak, nightmareish vision brought to life even more so with the huge collection of community made mods available.

This was the first game in the trilogy of games the other two being Call of Pripyat and Clear Sky (a prequal). Both of which are also incredible, CoP more so.

When you leave the Cordon for the first time after speaking to Wolf, walking up that path towards the road, turning and seeing your brothers slowly disappear into the distance, hearing the wind howl around the barrel of your creaky old shotgun, suddenly hearing some sort of demonic cry far away to the east and a chill creeps down your back. The sun is low in the musty sky - but just up ahead there is an old abandoned mill to explore, just make use of the fading light.

For me this game creates an atmosphere I've never felt before (or since, other STALKER titles not including) of a world gone to hell - the Zone, a huge area of land around the defunct Chernobyl reactor, now infested with nightmareish creatures deformed by radiation, different collections of (human) mostly factions wanting to kill you on sight and rob your last tin of tuna. Secret underground labs where horrific experiments happened before everything went to hell. Deserted farm buildings where blood hungry things lurk in the dark. STALKER is all about tension and fear, but also survival.

There are mods you can get that improve just about every aspect of the original game, textures, weapons, music, audio, bugs ironed out, even previously unnavailble areas.

I love STALKER, it's tremendously satisfying to survive in the Zone, it's terrifying, compelling and full of detail (if you also read all of lore/diary entries that Marked One enters into your PDA throughout the game.

For anybody that likes FPS/open world survival shooters with strong RPG elements, for anybody that loves to become really immersed in their chosen universe, there is nothing quite like STALKER.

Just don't forget your anti rads, and take care of Nimble - he's worth it.

reviewText:
In a nutshell, this game is:

10% Luck
20% Skill
15% Concentrated power of will
5% Pleasure
50% Pain

and 100% reason why to buy this game

As much as I enjoyed this game, your character kind of walks like a gangbanger from Compton, accuracy is annoying: unloading a whole magazine from a pistol or several shells into an enemy, you'll miss, even if they're in front of you. If you don't have bandages, you're screwed if you are hemorrhaging heavily.

This game, to me is like the Russian Fallout (even though Metro is considered the Russian Fallout to some people), I enjoy the layout and the weaponry in this game.

Weapons will degrade, ammo has weight, ammunition is scarce for some weapons.

Weight is an issue as you will slow down a whole lot if you hold onto several items, forcing you to drop loads of items or drinking a lot of energy drinks to get from Point A to Point B.

I would definitely recommend this game if you're looking for a challenge, this game has its horror moments, can be annoying at times but I would recommend it.

reviewText:
The first STALKER game, and the one that kicked off an amazing franchise. SOC is quite rough, but well worth playing through.

SOC is a fairly non-linear FPS with light RPG elements. RPG elements are mostly in the form of an inventory system and NPCs to converse with. Character progression is purely in the form of equipment, as you progress through the game you will find better weapons, outfits and artifacts (radioactive items that grant small defensive bonuses). There are plenty of side quests, mostly taking the form of repetitive fetch quests, but sometimes more complex.

What really sets the STALKER series apart from most games is the amazing atmosphere. The game has an extremely bleak and depressing atmosphere. The game is set in the Chernobyl Exclusion Zone, and contains many real world locations that the developers painstakingly researched.

SOC has an extremely active modding community, I would highly recommend skipping the highly publicised Complete" mod and instead playing with ZRP for your first playthrough. After a first playthrough with ZRP it might be worth trying out the Oblivion Lost or AMK mods
date: which make quite drastic changes to the gameplay."

reviewText:
DISCLAIMER: I am reviewing the completely vanilla, unmodded version of this game. I have heard there are many great mods, but my first playthrough was without any.

This game really was a joy to play. From the awesome world and the terrifying encounters,  to the unintentionally hilarious vodka overdoses and the cheeki breeki-ing, I really ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing liked it. The game has been compared to Fallout and other RPG post-apocalyptic survival games, but I like to classify it as it's own type of game. A game where the unknown frightens you and you are left fighting for survival where it seems everything is out to get you. The specifics of what I liked and disliked are recorded in the following paragraphs.
THINGS I LIKED:
1.First of all, this game has something really special, and equally hard to describe. To put it simply, the world seems to be alive in a way I haven't felt in many other games. Let me paint a picture: You come back to an outpost after a hard day of fighting bizzare mutations and equally bizzare bandits and sit down the fire by a complete stranger playing the guitar. As night falls, you enjoy a diet sausage and a bottle of vodka around the open fire in silence, treasuring these moments of peace. This is what I really love about this game. That is about the only way I can describe it. The feel of the world is Just sublme.
2. The core gameplay feels very solid. Guns kill suprisingly quickly and gunfights feel very tense, as if you are actually fighting for your life.
3. The story is presented in a unique and fascinating way.  You must learn about your world and what is happening through the PDAs of dead stalkers and dialogue with living ones. The story is subtle and leaves a lot up to speculation, in a way similar to Dark Souls, which I absolutely love.
4. Lastly, the game runs like a pro. Kind of a big deal if your computer is utter ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•, like mine.
That's what I liked, now here are the things that I kind of disliked (nit-picking ahead)
DISLIKES:
1. There are a few bugs, which can be expected from a game of this age, although I have read that the majority of them can be fixed with various mods.
2. Guns in the beginning are extremely inaccurate. This isn't necissarilly a con, but expect to be missing about 90% of your shots from anywhere over 20 meters until you find something that isn't a Kalashnikov variant.
3. The graphics aren't great. I say this, but the dull graphics kind of add to the game's gloomy mood. Again, if they aren't for you, there are a plethora of mods.
4. I like to pretend that the multiplayer doesn't exist.

CONSENSUS: I love this game. It is one of the most unique experiences that I have been a part of in a while. Whilethere are a few problems, I plan on playing through again with one of the many overhaul mods, which I heard can provied an even better experience. Will definately be checking out Call of Pripyat and Clear Sky.

NOTE: Helps if you speak Russian. Not a must, but adds to the immersion and authenticity.

reviewText:
THE SHORT REVIEW:
A cross between both Fallout and Metro, what's not to love about that? Shadow of Chernobyl is one of the best games of it's kind.

THE LONG REVIEW:
Shadow of Chernobyl has been in my Steam library (and backlog) for quite some time - haven't really had a chance to sit down and play the game, but after longing for something post-apocalyptic until Fallout 4, I'd thought that I would give this game a go. It's safe to say that Shadow of Chernobyl has become an instant favourite, and has immersed me within it's interesting world.

The gameplay is fairly simple, if you've played an FPS then you should come to expect the usual, but what makes SoC interesting is it's environments and it's desolate world. Even though I love Fallout, there were some parts that didn't really capture the feeling of lost-hope or desolation, SoC on the other hand nails it completely. It's an interesting blend between world building and exploration that makes me want to know everything about what's going on, there's not really a solid" story so your left to your own devices to investigate (at your own pace of course).

SoC has a great way of getting you to become distracted by the strange things
date: and this curiosity makes the game great to play. The gameplay
hoursPlayed: is slightly hindered by it's save system. It can become a hassle because you have to make sure you have at least more than one saves (or your screwed). Depending on where or when you save can mean life or a quick death
voteText: which can be a gamble when it might or might not help you out in the end.\n\nThough combat is great
helpfulPercent: it can often unforgiving as there are moments where you might pelt someone with a load of bullets followed by a swift death. Again
votesHelpful: depending on where you saved it might be the difference between having to redo a section or redo an entire quest. Luckily later on in the game you are given access to more formidable weapons making the combat much easier and quicker to complete.\n\nThere were moments where I was invested into the gameplay
votesTotal: and then there were other moments where I felt like I needed a break from it. It also doesn't help that the game lacks a fast travel system
votesFunny: but it does add to the immersion (which is always a plus in my book). I'm sure with the help of mods there will be a way to fix some of these issues
commentsCount: and I'm most certain I'll be using them on a second playthrough.\n\nShadow of Chernobyl is a first person shooter at heart

but it's certaintly one of the best survival games out there.

reviewText:
This is the first game i've sat and researched in 7 years and this is why...

Usually when I play games I switch off, hit keys/buttons and just zone out the day, s.t.a.l.k.e.r shadow of chernobyl does the absolute opposite. I have learned in my limited amount of playing that complacency equals death, there is no relaxing, there is no zoning out there is only concentration.

The atmosphere of the game, sound engineering, tonality of the setting and the ambience really give off that feeling that you aren't in a playground, you are in a world where one wrong corner and one stray bullet can stop you dead.

The best way the developers could get that message across to the player is when you first step out of sids bunker, there's a random series of beeps, the wind blows and sometimes a cat wails in what is probably its last moments.

The wind blows emptily through the tree's in the distance you can hear the droning about the zone being a deathtrap and a first time player can feel extremely out of their depth, confused and lost. That feeling of dread and confusion will stick to you throughout the game, that feeling is your survival instincts, a gut feeling you never really understood until now.

The first thing many players including myself learn is that you aren't  a walking death machine, you are frail and the zone let's you know that with a swift death, a death you will repeatedly see until the game crushes your precogniscent mindset on how you play shooters. You will reach a point where you will be angry and the game feels too hard and unfair but deep down, you know it was your own error that killed you so many times.

Learn the mantra: The zone gives with one hand and can take with the other."

reviewText:
The Stalker series is easily some of the most fun I've had playing a video game in recent memory, surpassing even AAA titles. This is the first, Shadow of Chernobyl, and it's a very enjoyable experience.

Now that that's out of the way, I'll move on to the important stuff.

When you fire up a STALKER game for the first time, one of two things will happen; either it will load without incident, or the game will crash. It's a fact of life; the sun shines, it's currenty 8:00 AM as I write this, and STALKER games like to crash for no particular reason. Disabling the Steam overlay in-game and fiddling with the graphics options, or disabling whatever mods you may have active seems to fix most problems, but sometimes you'll get a bug that, no matter what you do, will not go away. In that case, it's time to hit the Internet and hope that someone has a fix, which, more often than not, they do.

When you do get the game to work, start it on a higher difficulty than normal. Sounds stupid, but there's a reason for that. STALKER does a lot of weird things to the guns on lower difficulties, including making a certain amount of shots (both your's and the enemy's) fade completely out of existence before hitting the target. If you're wondering why your gun isn't hitting anything even thought you've got the crosshairs on your scope lined up right on the target's head, that's why. Also, everything on the low difficulties is a bullet sponge. You are too, but only until the end, where the enemies kill you by so much as staring in your general direction. You still die fast on the higher difficulties, but now the enemies will, too. Just remember to save often to prevent crashes from erasing the last hour of progress.

If you've gathered one things from that last paragraph, it's probably that the game is pretty hard. It is, although it's also fair. You die after a few hits, but so do most enemies that aren't armored or bigger than you. In addition, every human enemy can be instantly killed by shooting them in the head with any weapon in the game (although you will need armor piercing ammo to do the same for the guys in the late-game). If you can deal with the iron sights and semi-automatic fire rate on your assault rifle, you can get through the game without much issue, although it's still a good idea to invest in better guns and optics; the iron sights on all guns tend to be a little bit hard to find. By that, I mean that the sights are off, and the bullets like to go everywhere. On the starting Makarov handgun, for example, the sights resemble a brick set between two other, differently colored bricks (although, to be fair, this is how Makarov sights look in real life). The bullets also go a little higher than you would expect. The rifles have the same problems, but they can be fixed by grabbing a scope and slapping the two together. And hey, you can take the scope off when it's time to upgrade your equipment, so you're not stuck buying another one!

Speaking of equipment, there's weapon degradation in STALKER. The good news is that, unlike the other games, you can sell your stuff no matter how broken it is. The bad news is that there's no way to fix the stuff you like. So, if you found that Desert Eagle chambered for 9x39 rounds, you might want to be careful how you use it, because that gun absolutely wrecks everything and there's only one in the entire game.

Oh yes, there's also load times. They're not that bad, but there's a lot of them. Whenever you go into a new area, it takes a few seconds to load, so get used to that.

The good news is, that's pretty much the extent of the bad. Now, let's talk about the good.

STALKER has managed to blend elements of RPG games and FPS games in a good way. It's still a FPS game, mind you, and it doesn't have experience points or any way of leveling up, but it does have a healthy amount of inventory management. During my playthrough of this game, I spent more time messing about with my guns and ammo than I did in Resident Evil 4. Be warned that bringing up your inventory does not pause the game; you can still move while rearranging things, and enemies can still attack you. If you want to pause, hit the ESC key.

The Zone is an excellent setting full of whimsy and terror. I spent just as much time frolicking over hills while drinking enough vodka to give a troubled Soviet general alcohol poisoning as I did crawling through decrepit buildings with my flashlight on, hoping a Bloodsucker wasn't waiting around the next corner, ready to tear my throat out. It really captures what it feels like living in modern-day Russia, except Russia in real life has more mutants than in STALKER.

The guns are a bit finicky, but the shooting feels fun and rewarding. The recoil is harsher than in most games, which is all the more reason why you should use semi auto.

Disregarding the crashes, the game runs pretty well. I only saw it start to sputter in a few cases, and it actually didn't crash on me that much. I believe I had an issue where it crashed whenever I tried to start a new game, and after that, it crashed two or three more times, but both of those were fixed by just firing the game up again. It wasn't as bad as New Vegas, that's for sure.

So, should you buy STALKER: Shadow of Chernobyl? That depends. If you're a fan of open-world games like New Vegas, then you will enjoy this game. I highly recommend it.

reviewText:
OK, now i previously had a review written for this (and the other ones), but am going to pull a mulligan here.  When i wrote the reviews for the stalker series i based them off the Complete Mod.  Well, now i'm going to do one based off the vanilla experience.  In case anyone reads this VERY soon after publishing this, if you read the other stalker reviews before i've edited them, disregard them because they will be based on the Complete Mod.

So, where do i begin?  Oh yeah, the bugs.  For any new gamers playing this game....it's buggy as hell.  Thank God for mods.  This was the last of the 3 stalker games i played on vanilla because i heard so many bad things about the vanilla experience.  Let me just say this.....i REALLY wish i had played the vanilla game first before the mods, because you truly get a glimpse of just how difficult and demanding of focus this game is/demands.

It took me 5 years after release to buy this game because i kept seeing the letters R, P, and G.  Those 3 letters are a turn off to me because when i think of RPGs i think of relentless inventory management, grinding of situations to level up, and MILLIONS of side quests that make for a overlong experience thats full of filler....and more filler.  These 3 games managed to be FPS's with RPG ELEMENTS.  As i've learned while playing many of these types of games....this is what i like.  I like RPG elements.  Just not RPGs.  There is no filler here.  Sure, you have side quests to do, some of which pertain to the story, some don't.  Usually they take a matter of 5-10 minutes, so doing the numerous side quests doesn't feel like a drag.  And as far as the inventory management is concerned, you can only hold 50kg of weight, so you might have to drop something to make room for another.  However, this notion has a little bonus that i personally enjoy.....YOU ARE EXPOSED while accessing your inventory.  Nothing quite like checking to see how much ammo or money you have in the middle of a field when out of nowhere a bloodsucker comes and starts clawing at your face.....love it.

Now, on to more pressing matters.  First of all, story.  While i didn't do alot of research regarding the Chernobyl Nuclear meltdown in 1986, i did have knowledge of it happening.  What this game (and franchise for that matter) did, was open my eyes to the destructive wonder the zone has created.  An environment such as this is presented with this haunting, grimm, terrifying beauty.  It's hard stating that because of the real lives lost and the vacancy of a city of 50,000 people, but a real world event presented in a video game has managed to propel me to researching the city of Pripyat and the events of the meltdown.  Never before has a video game world captivated me so much.  Groups of people known as Stalkers travel to the zone for mysterious artifacts that provide a fortune.  Yet, even in a time of destruction humans cant seem to unite, and instead branch off into different factions.  Ever wonder why our world if this way?  Check out the story of Metro Last Light.....you'll see a glimmer of hope.  Anyway, you venture through the zone gearing up to battle other stalkers and mutants to reach the heart of the zone...The Nuclear Power Plant.  Wont spoil anymore.

The sound design is some of the best i've ever heard in any game. Never before had i played a game that made me jump out of my seat.  When you're walking through a corridor in an eroded lab with virtually no light and no ammo with a gun thats 10 bullets away from breaking in half, and the only sound you hear is either the growl of a controller or a pipe creaking, you're ready to take 2 steps back.  Such is life in the underground labs.

The artifacts provide an RPG element to the table that is the equivelent to supernatural powers.  They provide you with powers such as protection from anomalies, claw attacks, or added bullet protection.

Last but not least, the gameplay.  Now, my personal tastes of a sandbox game with no filler aside, this game has a decent length time.  A completionist run can be accomplished in about 25-30 hours, which i personally believe is a perfect length.  There is some inventory management, but with the realtime aspect, you wont be spending much time sifting through.  Your guns erode with use, meaning the accuracy is affected with extensive use and they can even jam.  Always make sure you carry a couple guns with you at all times.  Your armor also diminishes after taking some punches, which again, cause the protection to lessen.  As you lose armor, bullets and anomalies will do more damage to you.  Thankfully, with all the artifacts spread across the zone, money isn't an issue, so buying a new armor suit shouldn't be a problem.  But the biggest thing for new players reading this to know is, once you get about 3/4 the way through the game, there's no turning back.  You might not know when that moment is exactly, so be sure you're equipped for ANY situation.  This game is quite difficult, but there's a bit of a difficulty spike in the last 1/4 of the game.

It's one of those games that's oldschool, in the regard that it doesn't hold your hand.  Gamers are spoiled today by having everything spoon fed to them.  This game?  Not al all.  There is basically no tutorial and a steep learning curve.  If you ask me, it works well because it trains you to be on your toes.....and you need to be to finish this beast on the hardest skill level (which is where you should play it).  It's gritty, it's relentless, and it may cause some rage in the many deaths you may have, but somehow manages to be so rewarding at the same time.  Fantastic game, with even more potential if not for annoying bugs and a better optimized engine.

8.8/10

reviewText:
S.T.A.L.K.E.R. Shadow of Chernobyl is one of the most atmospheric shooter ever made, and in my opinion, one of the best shooters ever made.

The base game can be a real ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• to get working properly, and has many problems, but I wouldn't have 200 hours on this game if it didn't do something right. And bugs can be fixed with mods, and mods is another reason why I have so many hours on this game. The mods released for this game can completely change the experience and make it feel like you're playing the game for the first time again, and mods like ZoA, AMK, and LURK can extend the replayability to ridiculous levels, into the range of multiple thousand hours.

If you haven't played this yet, you are missing out on one of the greatest experiences in the shooter genre. Buy it, get the ZRP patches, turn the difficulty to Master, turn off your crosshair, and prepare to be immersed in one of the most interesting game universes out there. SoC has an atmosphere that many games can't manage to capture, not even it's own sequels. I strongly recommend you buy this as soon as possible.

reviewText:
Quite possibly the best game I have played in a long while.

The game itself is challenging with loads of NPCs who are quite capable of giving you a run for your money. They will almost always try to stay in cover and even flank you (including mutants). The game offers a massive open world with a variety of places to explore.

The storyline is marvelous, full of intrigue and is guaranteed to get you hooked and the variety of side quests will never let you get bored. Various factions react differently to your actions so keeping all of the Zone happy is tricky, but well worth it.

The shooting part of the game is realistic. Weapons can get stuck and can shoot blanks as well. From afar you won‚Äôt be able to hit jack ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•, but point blank, damage output is massive (especially with shotguns, go figure).
There are a few bugs, I am not gonna lie, such as some graphic issues, NPCs can get stuck inside of walls and obstacles etc.

And of course, best Cheeki Breeki experience.

Bottom line, if you‚Äôre looking for a good story and a game where you can explore I would highly recommend this as pros largely outweigh the cons.

9/10

reviewText:
S.T.A.L.K.E.R Shadow of Chernobyl is a game that should come with a warning label of sorts. It is a game that has that rough about to explode feeling that some of the more unpolished games tend to give off. The animation is a little off, the difficulty tends to jump all over the place, the text is often complete gibberish thanks to a shoddy Russian to English translation and the game is generally very unoptimized. Yet it's a fun game. Despite all it's flaws Shadow of Chernobyl manages to hit some of the right keys that makes it a great gaming experience.

Shadow of Chernobyl is an open-ended first person shooter taking place in and around the highly radioactive Chernobyl area. Now, this isn't the real world birth defect causing radiation, it's the more fun and cherry cartoon radiation that in this world causes mutated monster animals and a variety of spatial anomalies.

As you travel the world of S.T.A.L.K.E.R. you will encounter various factions fighting it out in the zone" as they call it

reviewText:
I'm late to the show. I first tried STALKER when it came out half a gaming century ago, but my rig sucked. I was pleased to see, that it runs like a charm on my relatively modern machine.

First of all: The game is old. Do not expect up to date visuals, do not expect to find a modern UI. Expect to move your hand a lot over the keyboard, because those hotkeys are scattered like they were in the day. Expect to push your mouse over buttons in menus.

You should also refrain from expecting a fast paced shooter. STALKER will kick your ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•. Do not expect to land a head shot with a pistol over long distances. STALKER features some pseudo realistic mechanics, which are not 1:1 real physics but give you a rough feeling about what it means to fire an old worn out gun during a rainy day at a moving target.

When I first launched the game and started moving around, I got a little dizzy, because the head bobbing is a little more than I can digest. It's an old but famous game, so naturally I looked for mods. The first hit brought me to a mod package, that tries to fix some bugs and combat annoyances, while trying to retain as much of the vanilla state as possible. Have a look at the Zone Reclamation Project".

The difficulty is good. I play on "Veteran"

reviewText: S.T.A.L.K.E.R. Shadow of Chernobyl is an FPS like none other. It combines the best parts of an FPS with the customization of RPGs and the jaw dropping suspense filled atmospheres of a horror game. 1986, the world's worst nuclear disaster occurred at the Chernobyl power station, but in the year 2006 a second explosion occurred causing even more mass destruction and chaos. Now all that there is left is wastelands filled with mutants, strange and bizarre anomalies, and serious amounts of radiation. It is now 2012 and you are awakened from a coma and find this PDA on you and all it says is to kill a man named Strelok. On your quest to find him you must traverse expansive lands and face the most ferocious of foes such as mutants, bandits, various faction members, and the military along with radiation and the many types of deadly anomalies. You have a huge arsenal of weapons,  various types of armor and a expansive world to explore for hours. I highly recommend this game.

reviewText:
This is hands down, the best single player game I have played. The atmosphere is fantastic and unlike any other game out there. it was in development for years and even though they didn't manage to include everything they wanted, what they did is still incredible. this is no Console shooter or port, if you want a simple run and gun don't buy it and play for 20 minutes and complain when unlike Crysis you can't kill everything in 10 seconds with your hi tech gun and invincible **** suit.


First of all, don't play it without downloading the Complete mod for free first. This updates the textures, sounds, AI, fixes a load of bugs and errors and makes the game what it wanted to be. It doesn't change anything, just cleans it all up.

This game isn't like other FPS because it is actually hard. You don't start off with an amazing gun and squad and intel, you have a coat and a pistol and aside from that you are on your own. The Zone is an easy place to die even without having a host of powerful mutants and heavily armed humans roaming around. This game doesn't hold your hand like Western shooters do, or load you up with amazing gear under the guise of being some Spec Ops soldier. The atmosphere is incredible, part's of it are creepy as hell and scary and not like the Doom3 teen equivalent of having a monster jump out when you press the door button or a loud bang etc. It is hard to get into because it is so unforgiving, and the first few maps and missions you are constantly trying to find a decent weapon that doesnt force you to retreat when outnumbered etc. If you want a linear shooter like HL2 or CoD with no freeplay, dialogue or exploration and lots of cutscenes then look elsewhere. There are plenty of games liek that around. if you want a slow hard atmospheric adventure then give it a try, turn out all the lights and play it till the sun comes up; call in sick and keep on playing.
10/10

reviewText:
STALKER Shadow of Chernobyl is my favorite game of all time. There's no way to properly express how fantastic it is. But I'll try I suppose.

The game takes place in Chernobyl, as the title suggests, though this Chernobyl is a much more mysterious one. After scientists went and messed around in Chernobyl after the disaster, weird crap started happening. Blowouts, anomalies, artifacts, and nasty warped mutants craving human flesh. The game is a mix between the real life place Chernobyl, obviously, mixed in with world and plot elements from the novel Roadside Picnic (which is my favorite book ever) and the film based on the book, Stalker (which is a great film too). I will never know why they picked that book, Chernobyl, and mutants in one game but one can only think it must've been some divine force that made it happen. The game is a lot like a realistic, Slavic, and overall more terrifying version of Fallout. Not saying that Fallout is bad though.

Gameplay is top-notch, the shooting is pretty great and going and finding artifacts can be really tricky. Depending on your alliances, you'll go up against either bandits, different factions, loners, or everyone. The fights are intense and may require many reloads before you figure out how to stump your enemies. This is not an easy game at all, even on the easier difficulties. It's hard as balls and will mess you up hard, you can't go without quicksaving. I'm not good at videogames, so it was a struggle to finish this one, but it was worth it.

I can't go talking about a game without talking about it's faults though, no matter how much I adore it. The AI is weird in this one... it goes from Vash the Stampede level of accuracy to the level of skill you'd expect from a drunk man. The graphics aren't exactly triple-A material either but the atmosphere and the overall visual design makes up for it.

STALKER: Shadow of Chernobyl is an interesting and unique title; there really isn't anything like it. It has its bugs and technical isssues, yes, but that won't stop me from loving truly awesome, scary, intense game. In the words of Number 6‚Ñ¢, There's nothing quite like Russian post-apocalyptic fiction

reviewText:
In this game you roam around a bleak landscape and dying horribly either to mutants, bullets, or radiation. And you will die because this game is pretty brutal in its difficulty. It also is filled with NPC's who hate the player character and tell you to go away and will likely shoot at you if you take too long.

It's also pretty good. It's post-apocalypse and almost a survival horror game where you have to worry constantly about lurking threats that will most certainly kill you if you are not careful. Also it has a pretty decent story, though one you can easily ignore due to the massive amounts of side-quests there are.

In short... it's kinda like a Russian Fallout, though set in Ukraine. It's quite similar to Metro 2033 in its atmosphere, though this game is an FPSRPG rather than just a straight shooter like that game is. This is the first in a series of three games (sadly there won't likely be anymore since the devs are dead), so if this series interests you at all, then this would be the likely starting point.

Have fun! :D

reviewText:
Stalker.. The person who enters/wanders through the zone from the Outside world. Help your character solve his Amnesia and discover the Truth.

Action Open world Survival Post-apocalyptic RPG with heavy atmosphere and well put story. Zone is one giant Death trap covered with Anomalies, Artifacts, Radiation, Mutants and Various fractions which you can either work for, kill or just ignore them.

Except the fact this game is quite a Bugfest I wouldn't find anything bad about it.
Quest characters going randomly to the anomalies suiciding one after another, Looped sounds playing even after load, constant random spam of Sidequests just for entering the area, Getting random quests you just can't complete because they weren't triggered correctly and many more.

Highly suggesting to install Zone Reclamation Project which mainly focuses just on bug fixes, seriously a lot, without adding any significant changes to the game itself from vanilla version.

The game is hard and boring in the beginning but rewarding in the end.

Good hunting.

reviewText:
This might probably be the most immersive and atmospheric shooter I have played to this day. Its strength mostly comes from the design of the world. You will see abandoned industrial districts, large radioactive wastelands and dark underground complexes with enemies, possibly around each corner. When travelling around the world you will encounter all kinds of characters: Neutral Stalkers, just like you, who are travelling the Zone looking for artifacts and trying to survive, Bandits who ambush you, trying to kill and loot you, or members of many different factions, which can be friendly or hostile, depending on your actions.
The world itself is very open and unscripted. Pretty much anything can happen, depending on who or what you will encounter. I want to tell a funny story about that:
I once took a sidequest which told me to kill a random target (These kind of quests are quite common and sometimes very challenging). Having a look on my map I saw that my target was very far away, so on my way there I did few different things. When I finally reached the sector, I saw a man in the distance being attacked and ripped apart by a horde of mutant dogs. In the second of his death I got the message that my quest was completed and returned for my undeserved reward.

The technical side of the game still has potential to be much better though, and that is where the mods kick in. Playing this completely vanilla is possible, but it is quite hard and will take some time to get used to it. I am not really one of those hardcoreplayers who are of the opinion that the first playthrough MUST be vanilla. You could go straight to the Stalker Complete Mod, which does a lot of things. It mainly is a graphical enhancement, which makes the already immersive environment look even better. Weapon animations are also a lot smoother and remove a lot of chunkiness of the gunplay. It also tweaks a few things around AI that makes stealth-oriented approaches atleast possible, which in some parts is a great addition.
Some say this makes the game too easy, but if you really think that after some playtime, I could recommend the Realistic Weapon Addon for the Complete mod to you, which basicly makes guns more lethal to both the enemies and the player. It improves the gunfights a lot and makes killing something quite satisfying, but still keeping it hard enough, because the player is vulnerable aswell.

reviewText:
I enjoy Deus Ex and System Shock 2 as much as the next person, but for me S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Shadow of Chernoybl towers over the first-person shooter genre.

It's that chilling feeling gotten by wondering across the bleak open landscape while hearing dogs howling in the distance (this being one of the very few games to be able to pull off outdoor daylight horror), It's that weird moment when you see some invisible monster for the first time and realise the game's surreal underbelly. It's the beautiful atmosphere created by the lightning. It's the tension built by running around trying to find that one last bit of radiation protection before you die of radiation poisoning. It's that feeling of satisfaction when you finally manage to fight your way through a group of clever AI enemies, or the stress built by panickingly trying to drink enough energy drink to simply run through them.

Or, more broadly - it's the perfect mixture of challenging difficulty, fantastic atmosphere and great survival mechanics which make it so special.

The game builds itself on creating tension through its inventory management system and creates such perfect results through it. Funnily enough, early in the game I found it annoying that managing your inventory doesn't pause the game and sometimes I stopped dead in the middle of combat because I was too heavy to move, but by the end I realised that was such an incredible way of building tension. S.T.A.L.K.E.R. is, after all, a game of scavenging and half the fun of the game is about deciding whether you can afford to go over to pillage a befallen enemy, work out what you need to take and if it's not too heavy to carry without getting killed.

But great survival mechanics and a really well balanced difficulty don't make a game on its own and the other main thing which really makes S.T.A.L.K.E.R. stand out is its gameworld. It's such a beautiful, desolate overworld and as much enjoyment as the challenge was just running over the baron plains with dogs howling and boars roaming around with some odd shots in the background. Even, the main homehub of Rostock has this incredibly eerie and desolate feel about it.

There's just this exquisite balance of challenge and ambience which make this the perfect FPS. Played alone, at night with headphones it is quite the experience.

reviewText: S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: SoC is, in my opinion, one of the most enthralling games I've ever played. I used to play it all the time on disc, but lost it a few years ago, but now, replaying it on Steam, It still holds up. The graphics overall are like graphics were just a few years ago, but mods have been made to update the graphics if you wish to change them. Glitches do tend to appear throughout the game, sometimes far between, or all the time from what I have heard, but I usually never see many glitches that destory my gaming experience while I play, because I usually tend to look over bugs. The combat is great, making you have to take cover and shoot from behind unless you want to be shot to pieces by enemies. Story is a-bit linear, but still very in-depth the further you get in the game. Side quests and the like aren't anything spectacular though, I usually never do any unless I need some quick cash. Overall, this is great game with some minor problems that can be fixed with mods. 8/10

reviewText:
A Paladin's Review: S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Shadow of Chernobyl. A World Alive With Potentially Horrifying Situations.Genre: FPS RPG Post-Apocalyptic Horror Open World.
Developed and Published by: GSC Game World
Platform: Windows Only.
Business Model: Base Game
Copy Purchased by Myself Read the full & unabridged review on A Paladin Without A Crusade[kingisaaclinksr.com]

Preamble
There are games that leave an impression for a lifetime and this is one of them. How else could I forget such a unique title as this? The world you explore and survive in feels alive unlike any other open-world game I've played to date or since. This is a game that has sent me through a whole range of emotions from fear to exultation at having succeeded at survived in the dark depths of the Labs....those labs...*shudder*. Good adventures always end bittersweet. It was constant anxiety with this one. I was never quite certain what was around the next corner. Always wondering if I would run into a pack of mutants ready to rip my face off or other more murderous STALKERs. This will be a spoiler-free review of the game and I'll do my best to cover what I can. S.T.A.L.K.E.R. Shadow of Chernobyl originally took over seven months for me to complete. Granted, I took a few breaks from the game which is why it took so long. According to Steam, I've logged over 41 hours with the game. Feels like the longest 41 hours of my life. The game made me as jumpy as a rabbit when playing it and some of the things in the game elicit such a fearful response that it made it difficult to play it. Is that silly? Maybe, but that's the fun of it as well. Even so, I still faced my fears down and finished the game. Only to begin jumping right into the sequel afterwards. I am a sucker for punishment.

Overall Gameplay Thoughts
Shadow of Chernobyl is such a unique game that it's hard to quantify all of what makes it so. When I had played this, I hadn't really been exposed to much of the horror genre and it's still not one of my favorite genres, except for psychological horror. Which I can only think it's because I want to overcome my fears. What better way to do it than in a world full of radiation, mutants and horrifying creatures. SoC is an FPS and RPG hybrid with lots of open world elements. There's a main quest to complete, lots of optional side missions that you're free to tackle and plenty of weapons to choose from. The big selling point for SoC (outside of its post-apocalyptic themes) is the A-Life engine. The A-Life engine allows creatures and NPCs to roam the wasteland with a set of guidelines and rules. They eat, sleep, move around, shoot enemies, talk to friends and generally act like human beings. In combat they avoid hazards, throw grenades and act tactically, sometimes sneaking up on you when you don't realize they're there. It isn't uncommon to see a skirmish between an important NPC and his vanguard against a random bunch of mutated dogs that were at one point on the other side of the field they were in. This world is unscripted which means that sometimes events such as a quest giver being attacked and killed can happen. And then you're completely unable to finish your quest. That's not intended to happen, but A-Life allows for it.

Oblivion Lost Mod & The Modding Community
My first run through of Shadow of Chernobyl was with the Oblivion Lost mod. You'll want to run this game with at least one mod to fix a lot of the issues the original game has. Due to a rushed development timetable, a lot of content and original ideas had been cut from the game. But, the modding community took it upon themselves to fix up the numerous issues and open the game up to the developer's original vision. One of the more popular mods is Oblivion Lost, which was recommended by Moonshinefox as the most optimal and true experience of SoC. You can find a full list of changes at this link[forums.filefront.com]. Suffice it to say, it makes the game shine. As an overview, the mod adds Emission events which happen at random times. If you're standing outside, they can kill you with a big old dose of radiation. Worse, it causes the anomalies to move around in the world, kills off NPCs that are also outside (potentially screwing up your quest) and also causes an increase in the number of mutated creatures. Yay. Oh and what are anomalies? They are areas where the laws of nature and physics have been corrupted and are dangerous/lethal to passing entities. There are anomalies of fire, electricity and so on. The mod also adds factions that interact/shoot at each other, weapons, random weather, artifact transmutations, better realism, and a lot of other things.

PC Settings & Modding
Settings are fairly reasonable and include most of what you need. However, some settings don't work such as the AA slider, it doesn't actually do anything and V-sync is completely broken. Fixing these problems will require installing a mod. You can check out the issues and modding solutions on PCGamingWiki[pcgamingwiki.com]. As for what settings do work, there's a reasonable selection of resolution options, gamma, contrast and brightness sliders. Advanced video options include vision distance, objects detail, grass density, textures detail, lighting, shadow quality and anisotropic filtering sliders. They don't give you any numbers to understand what you're changing though. Key rebinding and alternative keys are also available in the game. The only audio sliders are SFX and music though the game supports up to 7.0 surround sound.

Final Thoughts
This isn't a perfect game by any stretch. It has a lot of bugs and quirks that have been tackled by the modding community but it can still lead to some unfortunate situations while you're playing. Including but not limited to: being stuck in a level with no ammo and unable to move forward, wonky combat balance and NPCs behaving erratically. However, I think the Shadow of Chernobyl experience is worth the risk. It's steeped in atmosphere, the game engine makes the world feel truly alive even if it's heavily scripted and the richness of this Russian post-apocalyptic world is utterly unique. Sometimes the best games are the ones that are the messiest. It's a pity that there hasn't been any continuations in this genre but I hold out hope someday, someone will give it a go.

reviewText:
S.T.A.L.K.E.R. is one of the best games I have ever played. The level of detail placed into building its landscape and atmosphere pays off, making this game a fully immersive title. In terms of gameplay, I have found SOC to be in basic terms- a sandbox first person shooter. SOC is full of fun mechanics, realistic gunplay, and various artifacts to keep replayability going. My only complaint would be the game's AI, which at times may be too dumb or outright overpowered. In order to maintain this issue at bay, I would recommend playing the game at a normal difficulty setting.

+atmosphere
+story
+quests and artifacts
+fun concept
-AI may not cooperate
-occassional stutters

reviewText:
Best atmosphere of any video game possibly ever.. Cringeworthy AI/Combat bullet dmg however.

(The amazing atmosphere, guns, sounds, mutants, visuals of this game outweight the poor AI cons a million to one)

I am not mad or angry writing this review. I am perfectly calm. Not butthurt. I love that stalker exists and technically speaking is one of the most impressive fps game engines i've ever experienced. I am still enjoying the game right now actually. I know this will hurt your feelings bringing up some negatives but its what i observe from playing the game again in 2016

1.Terrible AI. Sadly this is true.

-Sometimes enemies will tactically walk into the room.. backwards??

-you can walk up to a bandit camp with a non-silenced rifle, shoot one of the three patrol guards in the head.. watch him drop.. then just watch his friends walk around his dead body like nothing happened.

-You shoot a guard, watch him flinch, see the blood spatter, and he will just continue patrolling without becoming alarmed or doing anything differently

-Enemies do not respond to sounds or flashlights, they just automatically face you when you come within 15ft of them (regardless if you are sneaking or not)

Once you get a little way into the game, It takes about 1-2 headshot to kill, or... 30-70 body shots. I wish i was being sarcastic. How could a game with so much realism ingrained into the atmosphere possibly have such an insultingly unrealistic bullet damage system? It takes smart people to make such a realistic engaging atmosphere like this. So i am surprised that they all collectively agreed on this arcade-like bullet damage system. I just wish it was more realistic (3-5 body shots for medium armor enemies, 7 body shots for heavy armor enemies)

**UPDATE** The above statement needs to be re-visited, yes it does take a lot of shots to kill an enemy.. But after playing for many more hours i have determined that this game is set up more like an RPG than a traditional FPS. It makes sense because the developers want you to come across better geared enemies as you go deeper through the game. Although it does feel silly having to shoot an enemy with 70 body shots at times.

So...Continuing with the horrors of AI. They rarely respond to gunshot sounds, if they do its completely incorrect and they walk to the wrong location

If you see an enemy in a window and fire at him, you would expect him to look out the window and return fire.. But no. The AI just gets confused, walks around in that room for a bit then crouches and aims at a wall until you walk upstairs and kill him as he stares at the wall.

If you are behind a big 6 inch steel wall or something, enemies will just shoot at the wall till the end of time

The game does have a lot of positive things too however, the graphics are top notch, the sounds are FLAWLESS, the controls and user interface is very fitting for the atmosphere..

reviewText:
STALKER: Shadow of Chernobyl is a difficult game to start, but rewarding to finish. I enjoyed this game more and more as I played; loved it by the end. Fantastic atmosphere.

The game is very grim and challenging. It plays mostly like an RPG, because you're taking on missions and learning a story as you go. But there are no levels, no experience points, and no skill tree, so in that regard it's somewhat like an FPS. It's also scary, and resources are scarce, so it bears elements of the survival horror genre, too.

The ending is satisfying. Unlike many RPGs that cop out with a boss battle, STALKER gives you answers and a conclusion that makes sense.

A few tips if you play. 1) Find and use the STALKER Complete" mod. It improves the graphics and the English translation
date: and fixes bugs. 2) It's OK to play on Novice -- you'll die plenty on any setting. 3) Use a game guide. It will help you with the weapons
recommended: and keep your story on track. I liked IGN's guide.\n"
