reviewText:
THIS GAME IS GREAT!!

Once upon a time, Doom and Fallout had a baby, and then gave it steroids. A lot of it. And thus, STALKER was born.

STALKER is an amazing series, with three games in the series, I have several days on this game, but Steam doesn't show it because I was offline while I played it. (Since I had no internet access at the time.)

With a huge map to explore, plenty of monsters to face, a large assortment of weapons, armor, and missions to do, this makes for a fun time.

STALKER: Shadow of Chernobyl is an open world FPS game. Taking place in the Chernobyl Exclusion Zone. Did you read that?!  THE FREAKIN' Chernobyl Exclusion Zone!  I even bolded it, just to show how awesome that is. The game is not creepy in a sense, but if you are prone to being frightened easily, a few areas of the game may give you a slight scare.

Pros:
Bro, this game takes place in Chernobyl, that's awesome in itself!
A huge map to explore.
Plenty of missions to do.
I large assortment of weapons and armor.
Treasure hunting!
Immense variety of enemies.
Different atmospheres and moods of tone.
A few scary and eerie places in the map.
A nice story. (Could use improvement.)
Challenging gameplay.
Good graphics.
Moddable.

But, of course, like all games, STALKER has some downsides we can't dismiss:

The game is highly buggy and glitchy. I had a big problem getting the game to work, and I still don't have it working fully.

LONG LOAD TIMES:  The load times are atrocious, and without doing some tweaking work, it will typically last from 10-15 minutes. Although settings can be changed, and mods can be installed to help this issue, it's still a problem. While the game loads, go take a shower, clean the house, or mow the lawn, it needs to be done anyways.

If you don't mind bugs and glitches, sit down, grab yourself some Cossack's Vodka, put on your Russian hat,  bring a bear into your house  buckle up, and enjoy the awesome ride this game has to offer!

PS: Don't actually bring a bear into your house.

reviewText:
One of the best shooters I've ever played. Can be frustrating due to poor translation and a confusing system of timed side-quests which automatically assign and fail regularly. Learning to ignore these is a leap of faith necessary to enjoy the game.

Once you're past its failings, STALKER is pure and often terrifying fun. Lots of space to roam, a solid item system, believable and intricate interiors. Friendly wanderers, roaming bandits; real choice in weapons & armor rather than your usual planned-out, linear upgrades.

For the frustrated, there are mods out there which fix the translation, alter NPC behavior, permit equipment repair, and so on. If you forgo these, be advised that the first two areas are extremely difficult due to your weak equipment, so avoiding combat there is usually the smart move. There will be plenty of time for payback later.

All in all, a flawed but irreplaceable classic which is not for everyone, but which everyone should try.

reviewText:
The S.T.A.L.K.E.R series of games is my favorite series of games; Let me preface this review with that statement.


Do you like Atmosphere?
Do you like a challenging, rewarding experience?
Do you like the feeling of helplessness, that edge of adrenaline as something that can snap you like a twig without lifting a finger?

If the answer to any of these questions is yes, then this will be a very rewarding game in every aspect of the way. The S.T.A.L.K.E.R series, specifically, Shadow of Chernobyl, is iconic for it's atmosphere so thick it drips out of your screen. The distant sounds of assault rifle fire as you clutch your rusty Kalishnikov to your chest are always terrifying. Is it bandits? Is it a local militia trying to fight off some horrible mutant? You'll always feel vulnerable in the wide, gray fields that make up much of S.T.A.L.K.E.R's landscapes. But don't think running for cover inside will make you safer.. Buildings can be home to traps set by enemies, a bandit camp, or a vicious Bloodsucker's lair.

The game mechanics are solid, if abit stiff. You'll never feel cheated if you die; This game is much alike Dark Souls in that regard. However, if you play on any difficulty above Stalker, expect frequent deaths; I reccomend Master, but that's just me. Fortunately, the game features a fairly primitive, if not effective quicksave/load system.

Many weapons feel powerful and give feedback; The thunder as you unload a clip from the shiny gun you found on a corpse will always light up the darkness and make you feel alittle less vunerable. Don't take it as a sign of invincibility - Often, you'll be found a few bullets short, gun empty and useless as something with razor-sharp teeth and claws advances on you. However, unless you play a stealthy character, often your knife will be next to useless in combat; As will many of the game's sidearms, unless your primary's run dry.

The game also features enemies of the variety of the environment; Anamolies.
They're results of the radiation that envelopes the zone, and they're very dangerous; being anything from Static electricty that'll light you up like a christmas tree, to a minature vortex that pulls skin from the bone. All are usually dangerous, but the name of the game in S.T.A.L.K.E.R are the results of Anamolies; Artifacts. They're mysterious objects that grant mystical properties on the human body, from massively increased healing to bullet resistance.

Of course, the game isn't flawless. There's many glitches in A.I., but you can't fault a game made in 2007 from a third party company for having some weaknesses. The number one problem with the game is it's voice acting and it's graphics - Even for the time it was released, it wasn't a pretty game. The voice acting is generally pretty atrocious, when it's there - Two of the more famous memes from the game result from this; (Come eehn! Doan juss stah ther!) (GEET OUYT OFF HEER STALKHERR), but overall, that's not the game's strength.

Out of the three games, Shadow of Chernobyl, Clear Sky, and Call of Pripyat; I would hesitate in calling this one the best. The other two have far stronger mechanical changes, as well as generally improved voiceacting and graphics.. However, Shadow of Chernobyl will always be the strongest in terms of the feel it gives you. You feel helpless, weak, and scared. Your life is valuable, and the zone can snatch it in an instant. The game doesn't baby you, nor does it hold back. You will die, and you'll love every second if you're a junkie for the things I've mentioned.



IF TL:DR, LOOK HERE.



Overall..[Starting score of 5 - An average game.]

-PROS-
Fantastic, immersive atmosphere (+2.5)
A unique story and universe (+1.5)
A powerful way to improve your character via artifacts (+1)
Solid, if stiff mechanics (+1)

-CONS-
Glitchy, sometimes outright broken A.I. (-1)
Horrendous Voice Acting (-1)
Often uninventive areas (-1)

-TOTAL-
-8.0-
A powerful but sometimes unintuitive experience. It'll be memorable for it's unique combat, lore, and mechanics, but occasionally the things that bring down the experience really bring it down. Several times does it show off it's impressive concept of an apocalyptic world, but once or twice it falls short. If you're a fan of a deep, immersive game that'll take you a week or more to complete simply from just how difficult it can be, then this game's your one-trick pony. If not, you might be able to get some enjoyment from the pure russian that this game is. If not, then it likely isn't your sort of game.

reviewText:
Living in the Zone, life can be tough. No, life IS tough. Anomolies waiting to tear you apart, radiation sitting everywhere, freaks of the zone gaining territory by ripping apart anyone in their vicinity, factions battling for control, bandits causing chaos, and the military attempting to put a stop to everything permenantly. The zone is a painful, unforgiving place, in which one mistake could lead you to your end. Welcome to S.T.A.L.K.E.R..

S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Shadow of Chernobyl is one of the three games from the S.T.A.L.K.E.R. series. In S.T.A.L.K.E.R., you are a man living inside of the zone. Following the explosion of the chernobyl reactor, the radiation and other unkown forces created the zone. Anomolies, mutants, radiation, and other hazards litter the zone. The anomolies within the zone have the power to create artificats, objects defying physics and producing astronomical results. Catching the worlds attention, these artificats quickly became sought after, with people like you heading into the zone to retrieve them. Normal men, looters, murderers, bandits, rapists, all types of men flocked over to the zone to become rich. These men would eventually be known as stalkers. In this game, you are one of these men, trying to uncover the mystery of the zone while also trying to uncover your memory and how an assasination order came into your hands.

So how's the gameplay? Extremely brutal. The game doesn't explain anything, it doesn't hold your hand, there is no guidance towards what you do. Things are out to get you, bandits wanting your stuff, military wanting to put a bullet between your eyes with a sniper. There is nothing safe in the zone. You become genuinly scared of the zone, and when the first night hits, you simply want to put yourself in some attic and wait out the night so the things making noises could go away.

Actual gameplay wise, it's a standard FPS with some RPG elements. Lots of focus has been put into the guns, the enviroment, and making it feel like a real shooter in a lawless land. This is not Doom styled gameplay of megasprinting everywhere, this is serious tactical gameplay of where you plan everything ahead, shoot good and shoot fast. Utilize the lean mechanics and the enviroment to stay alive the best you can. The weight limit is low and unforgiving, bleeding and radiation constantly nag at your health, and if you step into an anomoly you can consider yourself dead. Supplies are extremely scarce, and the game loves teasing you with it. One time I set out to scale a destroyed building, a task which proved to be immensly difficult. This is the game if you want a serious, tactical shooter set in one of the most scariest enviroments I have ever played. This isn't a horror game, but it sure as hell felt like one later on in the game. This is Fallout for men. A serious dose of Russian, Vodka, AK-47s, bandits, and mutants.

reviewText:
The only game of this trilogy, this franchise that I am happy to recommend to everybody out there who like post-apocalyptic FPS games. While post-apocalyptic reminds many of us of Fallout 3, Stalker's surroundings are different and instead of the barren lands full of debris you have to imagine a nuclear wasteland.

This wasteland is called the Zone and interestingly, the game follows the catastrophe of Chernobyl by adding a twist to the story: here the activities in the power plant did not stop after the incident, in fact, quite the opposite happened which was eventually followed by another explosion. Now, this huge radioactive area is fully of anomalies and mutants and of course stalkers, mercenaries who are obsessed with all this and aim to find all kinds of artifacts that are the results of the catastrophe.

While the game was released back in 2007 it should be noted that a mod called COMPLETE is available to enhance everything in the game: it ups the visuals, lowers the amount of bugs and glitches and even adds new features to make the gameplay easier and more exciting.

The game offers a free-roaming system: missions can be triggered after speaking with various individuals, other than that you are free to go wherever you want and whenever you want. There are many side missions, too, that lengthen an already long story and as the game offers at least half a dozen endings in the form of rendered cutscenes you have a high replayability value here.

One of the downsides for me was that I was not exactly notified that once I start a particular mission there will be no return. With the COMPLETE mod this is now corrected as after completing the story the game puts you back in the Zone and you are free to complete any pending missions you had. Another thing was the difficulty - I have played a lot of FPS games and these I usually complete on hard difficulty settings, too, so I consider myself a veteran but even Stalker was too difficult at times. I believe it is an AI issue as enemies can easily give you headshots from a far distance and there's no room for suprises attacks, either. They are just too good so quick-saving is recommended frequently.

Stalker is a classic. It may not be a beautiful game but its gameplay is certainly entertaining and unique. With the COMPLETE mod in place it is an even better experience.

reviewText:
The S.T.A.L.K.E.R series of games is my favorite series of games; Let me preface this review with that statement.


Do you like Atmosphere?
Do you like a challenging, rewarding experience?
Do you like the feeling of helplessness, that edge of adrenaline as something that can snap you like a twig without lifting a finger?

If the answer to any of these questions is yes, then this will be a very rewarding game in every aspect of the way. The S.T.A.L.K.E.R series, specifically, Shadow of Chernobyl, is iconic for it's atmosphere so thick it drips out of your screen. The distant sounds of assault rifle fire as you clutch your rusty Kalishnikov to your chest are always terrifying. Is it bandits? Is it a local militia trying to fight off some horrible mutant? You'll always feel vulnerable in the wide, gray fields that make up much of S.T.A.L.K.E.R's landscapes. But don't think running for cover inside will make you safer.. Buildings can be home to traps set by enemies, a bandit camp, or a vicious Bloodsucker's lair.

The game mechanics are solid, if abit stiff. You'll never feel cheated if you die; This game is much alike Dark Souls in that regard. However, if you play on any difficulty above Stalker, expect frequent deaths; I reccomend Master, but that's just me. Fortunately, the game features a fairly primitive, if not effective quicksave/load system.

Many weapons feel powerful and give feedback; The thunder as you unload a clip from the shiny gun you found on a corpse will always light up the darkness and make you feel alittle less vunerable. Don't take it as a sign of invincibility - Often, you'll be found a few bullets short, gun empty and useless as something with razor-sharp teeth and claws advances on you. However, unless you play a stealthy character, often your knife will be next to useless in combat; As will many of the game's sidearms, unless your primary's run dry.

The game also features enemies of the variety of the environment; Anamolies.
They're results of the radiation that envelopes the zone, and they're very dangerous; being anything from Static electricty that'll light you up like a christmas tree, to a minature vortex that pulls skin from the bone. All are usually dangerous, but the name of the game in S.T.A.L.K.E.R are the results of Anamolies; Artifacts. They're mysterious objects that grant mystical properties on the human body, from massively increased healing to bullet resistance.

Of course, the game isn't flawless. There's many glitches in A.I., but you can't fault a game made in 2007 from a third party company for having some weaknesses. The number one problem with the game is it's voice acting and it's graphics - Even for the time it was released, it wasn't a pretty game. The voice acting is generally pretty atrocious, when it's there - Two of the more famous memes from the game result from this; (Come eehn! Doan juss stah ther!) (GEET OUYT OFF HEER STALKHERR), but overall, that's not the game's strength.

Out of the three games, Shadow of Chernobyl, Clear Sky, and Call of Pripyat; I would hesitate in calling this one the best. The other two have far stronger mechanical changes, as well as generally improved voiceacting and graphics.. However, Shadow of Chernobyl will always be the strongest in terms of the feel it gives you. You feel helpless, weak, and scared. Your life is valuable, and the zone can snatch it in an instant. The game doesn't baby you, nor does it hold back. You will die, and you'll love every second if you're a junkie for the things I've mentioned.



IF TL:DR, LOOK HERE.



Overall..[Starting score of 5 - An average game.]

-PROS-
Fantastic, immersive atmosphere (+2.5)
A unique story and universe (+1.5)
A powerful way to improve your character via artifacts (+1)
Solid, if stiff mechanics (+1)

-CONS-
Glitchy, sometimes outright broken A.I. (-1)
Horrendous Voice Acting (-1)
Often uninventive areas (-1)

-TOTAL-
-8.0-
A powerful but sometimes unintuitive experience. It'll be memorable for it's unique combat, lore, and mechanics, but occasionally the things that bring down the experience really bring it down. Several times does it show off it's impressive concept of an apocalyptic world, but once or twice it falls short. If you're a fan of a deep, immersive game that'll take you a week or more to complete simply from just how difficult it can be, then this game's your one-trick pony. If not, you might be able to get some enjoyment from the pure russian that this game is. If not, then it likely isn't your sort of game.

reviewText:
Hundreds of hours invested in this on the disc version purchased many moons ago. STALKER is a bleak, nightmareish vision brought to life even more so with the huge collection of community made mods available.

This was the first game in the trilogy of games the other two being Call of Pripyat and Clear Sky (a prequal). Both of which are also incredible, CoP more so.

When you leave the Cordon for the first time after speaking to Wolf, walking up that path towards the road, turning and seeing your brothers slowly disappear into the distance, hearing the wind howl around the barrel of your creaky old shotgun, suddenly hearing some sort of demonic cry far away to the east and a chill creeps down your back. The sun is low in the musty sky - but just up ahead there is an old abandoned mill to explore, just make use of the fading light.

For me this game creates an atmosphere I've never felt before (or since, other STALKER titles not including) of a world gone to hell - the Zone, a huge area of land around the defunct Chernobyl reactor, now infested with nightmareish creatures deformed by radiation, different collections of (human) mostly factions wanting to kill you on sight and rob your last tin of tuna. Secret underground labs where horrific experiments happened before everything went to hell. Deserted farm buildings where blood hungry things lurk in the dark. STALKER is all about tension and fear, but also survival.

There are mods you can get that improve just about every aspect of the original game, textures, weapons, music, audio, bugs ironed out, even previously unnavailble areas.

I love STALKER, it's tremendously satisfying to survive in the Zone, it's terrifying, compelling and full of detail (if you also read all of lore/diary entries that Marked One enters into your PDA throughout the game.

For anybody that likes FPS/open world survival shooters with strong RPG elements, for anybody that loves to become really immersed in their chosen universe, there is nothing quite like STALKER.

Just don't forget your anti rads, and take care of Nimble - he's worth it.

reviewText:
Rating 8.5/10
Overview: First Person Shooter

Note: I used the complete mod 2012 to play the game.

The Good:

+ The atmosphere is probably the main standout for the game. The setting, locations and realistic art style really showcase the destruction of the Chernobyl incident.  The developers really nailed being in a destroyed post apocalyptic  nuclear death zone. Buildings are crumbling and dilapidated, broken vehicles litter the roads, small settlements of makeshift homes and building house some of the other inhabitants on the 'zone'. Every aspect of the game facilitates you feeling like you need to survive. The game has a lot of contrast between the outdoor and indoor environment. When your outside with the sun shining, things don't look all that bad despite being surround by destroyed buildings and vehicles. Indoors is a different matter, things are dark, gloomy and taking your time is advised unless you want a quick death. No matter where you are, it's hard not to soak in the atmosphere this game has to offer.

+ The lighting effects are incredible. The lighting effects really shine when your indoors fighting enemies with flashlights and you see all the shadows being cast from every object in the room. The fact that this is an almost decade old game with a mod makes this graphical feature even more incredible.

+ Level design really standouts and just adds to the overall game play. The game has an over world split into different sections. Each section isn't too big and can easily be traversed from end to end in a short amount of time. Each section is designed differently depending on how far you are from the main city. Most areas consist of buildings and landscapes where more of the gun battles take place.

+ The game features some of the most impressive AI I have seen since FEAR. Enemies will flank you if you don't pay attention, work together and carefully use the environment around them to get the upper hand.

+ Gun battles are fun, challenging and require some thought. Charging head first into a gun fight will result in a quick death. Combine this with the impressive level design and AI and you get some truly amazing gun fights in this game.

+ Game play consists of killing enemies as you traverse 'the zone', scavenging dead bodies and loot to find weapons, armor, ammo, health etc. Survival is a main underlying component with the game. Weapons and armor degrade over time making them less effective and need to be fixed or replaced, radiation levels have to be checked, getting shot or attacked by mutant animals require you to use bandages to stop bleeding, eating is required every so often and you also need to watch your weight limit. Carry too much and your stamina runs out very quickly forcing you to stop or walk until you regain it back.

+ The game has an interesting story albeit starts off very clich√©. You start with amnesia with a quest to kill someone on your PDA. The story unfolds slowly after that. The game has different endings depending on whether you completed certain missions or not which is also nice

+ The game has items called artifacts that when equipped grant you certain benefits in one stat but lowers other stats. You can equip up to five and which ones you equip depends largely on your play style. It provides a nice light rpg element to the game.

+ Strong mod community

+ Sound effects

The Average:

Difficulty is fairly balanced for most of the game but becomes problematic in the later sections of the game where enemies can one shot kill you leading to some very frustrating moments. Quick save/load become your best friend in moments like these.

Load times in-between sections can be annoying and sometimes long

The Bad:

- This game has some of the worst stuttering I have ever seen. At first I thought my computer couldn't handle it until I read many other people were having the exact same problem.

- The game has generic side quests. I.e. go to a location and kill enemies or find an item. The side quests are not engaging nor are they fun and they add very little to the story. The second problem is that there is little incentive to complete any of these quests in the first place. The majority of the rewards are not great and you can easily get most of the money/items from fallen enemies and loot stashes.

- No fast travel exists in the vanilla version of the game making side quests even more tedious which may frustrate players. The mod I was using added a fast travel option.

Conclusion:

I've heard nothing but great things about this game so I'm finally glad I was able to play it. Technically it is rough around the edges but the good more than make up for it. Highly Recommended

reviewText:
I like others became enamored with this title prior to release.  It was in a class of its own for graphics, and aledged gameplay.

I managed to get a CD copy on release, and loved it....Glitches and crashes were common, but somehow seemed normal.  Years later this game has been patched up.  Modifications small and large have been on the scene for years.  This game is totally stable as of 2016, and still totally wonderful.

This is one of the best FPS titles I have ever played.  The story is unique, and draws players in.....  The atmosphere of the game is so real, that at times it is best to walk away for a bit and make sure you are not part of it.

Easily a classic in my book.  I Have bought this game at least a half a dozen times on steam.  For myself, for my family and friends.  It is worth it.

Years later, I have somehow lost the physical copy....But my pc has not had a CD drive in years....It may very well have been in the drive when it was removed, and unresponsive.  Hopefully someone at the recycling center found that cd and enjoyed it as much as I did.

Buy this game.  It is a FPS survival horror that sets the bar higher than most ever expected it would.  It has some RPG" elements that add to the experience.


Of the STALKER series
date: this one is (my opinion) the best.  It has the most depth
recommended: and challenges you to balance all parts of your quest throughout an irradiated wasteland.  I find that no matter how often I return to this game

reviewText: STALKER is an example of a game that has numerous flaws, and yet manages to be amazing.  In fact, despite its bugs, unfinished and missing content, janky world etc. has managed to find a spot in my top 10 most beloved games of all time.  Not only that, it is the one game that has sold me on the concept of a survival game.  The Zone is a trecherous, scary place that is caked in so much atmopshere that it's hard not to feel as though every step you take is one step closer to your own untimely demise, and nothing is as satisfying as making it out of a rough encounter without bleeding to death or barely escaping an irradiated area after you realized you didn't pack enough anti-rads.  You are NEVER safe in this game.  Ever.  Admittedly Shadow of Chernobyl is the most linear of the three STALKER games, but honestly each one is cheap enough that you should just get all 3.  If you want a more open world, then play Clear Sky or even better Call of Pripyat.  But Shadow fo Chernobyl is still a gripping experience and a great starting point for this wonderful, creepy world - and there are lots of mods out there worth checking out, as well as the excellent standalone game STALKER: Lost Alpha which seeks to recreate STALKER based on its original design document and the many features that were cut during its lengthy 6 year development time.  Definitely check this one out.

reviewText: Every now and then a game which is one-of-a-kind and offers a completely unforgettable experience is made. This is one of those games. If you haven't tried S.T.A.L.K.E.R. before then now is the time. This FPS/RPG provides a realistic experience through proper weapon and damage mechanics and a special A-Life" AI engine which allows The Zone to continue living and changing even when the player isn't there. This game does not provide an easy start for newcomers
date: dropping you into the harsh and desolate Zone with nothing but a jacket and a pistol. But it will reward players who continue onward using common sense and quick judgement to overcome the myriad of obstacles on their journey to the Center of The Zone. If you haven't tried this game
recommended: try it. But don't try for 5 minutes and then give up because it's "too hard". Give it a couple of hours and in those hours think to yourself "If I was actually in The Zone
hoursPlayed: what would I do?"\n\nGood hunting S.T.A.L.K.E.R. See you in The Zone."

reviewText:
A good survival-FPS I must say.Very much alike to the fallout series yet FPS becomes more dominant than RPG in this game.You can be a ninja and melee a group of super-mutants in fallout due to its rpg elements(perks,poweramor,etc),yet in STALKER you can only rely on your headshot skills and pray that the little bandit you are fighting won't throw a god-damn grenade right below your belt without even seeing where you are(And they hit the spot every time!).Current working on it and hope to beat it soon so I can get my hands on its sequel I've just bought.
Anyway here are some pros and cons to summarize:
Pros:
1.Realistic pack-limit.When you play an open-world rpg,I bet most of you have developed a habit of looting every foe you kill and take everything so you can sell to a merchant to make money.Yet in this game you will find out soon enough that you can only carry so LITTLE.Normally I carry a rifle,one elite rifle just in case and a side arm pistol,some ammo,and a few bandages,medkits,anti-rads,and some everyday stuff.And THAT's ALL YOU CAN CARRY,if you loot and take everything from your enemy's corpse you won't get tired really fast(exceeding your pack limit) or even become completely immobilized(10 kg above your pack limit).
2. Fantastic night sight and weather system.(Probably have some thing to do with the STALKER COMPLETE 2009 MOD)
When the sun sets.It'be better if you crawled into your sleeping bag and actually sleep like in real life.If you dare to venture out at night you will find it hard to survive as you will either:A.Turn on the flash light and become a easy target and die quickly.B Turn off the flash and you can's see ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•!And also he weather system will change your sensibility and the sensibility of your enemies.During a rainy night the sounds will cover your footsteps for a sneak-in slit throat and you may be able to detect your enemy via the moonlight on a clear night.
3.Atmosphere and sound effects are captivating.You can sometimes here the howl of a monster or some distant gunshots in a vast plain,as where as strange the cry of babies when you ventured in some underground tunnels.They really creates a horrifying atmosphere as if you are really in a apocalypse.And when you finally make it to a camp and take a deep breath,you will find it extremely comforting to see one of the fellow stalkers take out a guitar and slowly plays some gentle Russian folk tunes.
Cons:
1.Just like fallout ,the survival element aren't emphasized enough.The game time elapse the same speed in real world so you won't get hungry normally in one gameplay experience (say 2hours).You can manually speed up the time though and you will find soon enough when it gets dark and you can't see anything and regret changing that!(Sight at night is a pro BTW).
2.Weapons feels really strange to handle.It feels like neither the normal FPS type(COD,Metro,Farcry,etc) nor the shooting simulator type(ARMA,Red Orchestra,etc).It just feels so strange,can't really tell what's wrong.
3.No quick-save option.Even if you can do it via the COMPLETE MOD,you will generate a save file every time you quick save and I JUST DELETE 1GB of saves after about 5 hours of gameplay. And there's no quick travel mechanics as well.(The Mod add a teleport option and that literally means TELEPORT(1000 miles in 0 seconds and you can teleport to somewhere you haven't even been to)
To conclude,as a fallout and survival game fan I STRONGLY RECOMMEND THIS GAME.

reviewText:
Where do I start with this game? I've played through it twice and am currently on my third play through after beating the trilogy a few years ago. I downloaded the STALKER Complete 2009 mod which I hoped would refresh the game without introducing stupid gameplay imbalances. I was right. It's still one of the greatest and most demanding open-world first person role playing games out there. And I think I would be justified in saying that it on its own rivals the AAA competitors like Fallout 3 or New Vegas. It's just that good.

It plays really nicely, and because it's such an old game it runs smoothly with high anti-aliasing and high frame rates. As a core game you are sort of thrown into the combat with little preparation, but it doesn't take an experienced shooter-player to realize that you need to duck and cover. Leaning is super important, and enemies like to shoot when you move forcing you to play patiently and not go commando. That being said, once you get the formula down, you just sit and pop enemies when they poke their heads out. Pretty standard. The real challenge is fighting monsters which will scare the ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• out of you and really put your twitch-shooter skills to the test. Interacting with friendlies and setting out on quests is easy enough, but oftentimes the quests will end in ways you don't expect due to the uncertain nature of everything occurring in the game-world. You plan an ambush with some buddies and only you made it out? That's your fault but you gotta move on.

The Complete 2009 mod really polishes off the game nicely. Textures are still pretty sharp, and the world is brimming with anomalies and enemies. You really notice the subtle touches like rain pouring outside and forcing friendlies to huddle inside next to barrel stoves. The sound is good but definitely dated. I really like having to use directional sound to orient myself and in a game like this that feature really stands out. The day-night cycles are intense and I found myself sleeping through the nights so as to have a daylight advantage in combat.

The story is super intriguing and really enhanced by the dark and radioactive atmosphere. Everything could be dangerous and you gotta be on your game if you want to make it out alive. What's awesome is that you can play this game multiple times and get fairly different experiences in terms of the narrative and your late-game character's attributes. Some people go full ecologist and collect anomalies to enhance their character. Some seek the best guns ever. Some have the best armor. It's all pretty standard for the genre, but it is executed well and provides a player with a large range of choices to make throughout the story.

Addendum: So I beat it after reloading a quick save every 15 minutes because holy ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• the monolith stalkers really throw everything in the game at you including gunships, mutants, armor piercing ammunition, and their sheer numbers (I killed maybe 40 in the last part of the game?). I don't want to spoil the ending so I won't, but I will address the incoherence" some people claim the game's story is guilty of. I am pretty sure that the curators that made that claim were either skipping through all the dialogue

reviewText:
Think Metro 2033 but more sandboxy and with more realistic gameplay.
Or Operation Flashpoint but you are the Russians and it's fun.

All that said, the first time I bought Stalker and loaded it up I only lasted a hour before it bailed out on me and crashed repeatedly everytime I tried playing it. A game that I can't play 0/10.
About three years later I made a second attempt, this time with a new computer. I began running around waving a pistol around in a environment that looked like it was built by a map editor on a Sunday afternoon. It could have had a better start, but better starts nothing when I realized how much I enjoyed it while engaged in street-level fighting armed with a laser rifle while backed by some cheap knockoffs of the Brotherhoods of Steel from Fallout 3. All this in day long gaming sessions that would generally be considered 'unhealthy' by those who have successful social lives. But it's a testament for how addicitng and honest-to-god engaging this game was for me with its sense of realism, acute open-worldiness, and how I feel like I am treated like someone with brains if I want to win rather than the tiptoe-through-the-garden-markers-on-every-interactable that so many other games *cough Assassin's Creed cough* do.

I really don't know why I'm constantly comparing Stalker to other games, but let it be said that Stalker did come out in 2003, before all of them, so let's put a big medal for originality then eh?
8.5/10

reviewText:
This game has had a pretty notorious reputation not long after it was announced in the early 2000's. It underwent numerous different designs, names, and builds before finally getting released in late 2007. Even then, some felt that the game was still a rushed beta, and honestly it was. It wasn't until several patches that the game was decently stable. However to many people, the game's now-trademark atmosphere, brutal gameplay and unforgiving gameplay environment were enough to leave the game permanently ingrained in gamer's minds across the globe.

Flash forward to 2013, and this game still has a devoted modding community who are regularly working on and releasing ambitious new total conversions, weapon packs, gameplay tweaks and even restorations of previously-cut content.

This game must be experienced first-hand. Even the base 2007 game is still good today, though the game truly shines once one ventures out and starts downloading various mods that make the game several orders of magnitude better. This reviewer here prefers 'Oblivion Lost 2.2', which is based on a previous version of the game -- it restores many gameplay concepts and features that were left out for reasons unknown. It adds in more weapons, more suits, creatures, improved graphics, smoother performance, vehicles, and even free-play. It also adds in complete A-Life, which is unlocked after a player beats the game with the best ending, where every STALKER in the Zone begins to operately totally freely, which can open up many unique scenarios which no two players will experience the same.

The story is fairly gripping, though players expecting constant cutscenes and characters who never shut up will be disappointed. The story is told primarily through notes left in PDA's and some interactions with other humans face-to-face, though the few cutscenes there are do a wonderful job of contributing to the haunting atmosphere the game promotes.

The gameplay is tough and unforgiving -- this game isn't for the noobs out there. You won't be charging at enemies doing 1080-degree backflips while going for no-scopes here. You have to pick your shots and battles carefully. Sometimes it's better to flee than fight, or use stealth to completely dodge enemies (or ambush them to take their loot!)

STALKER in essence is an FPSRPG. You've got the traditional first-person shooter gameplay, combined with an inventory system, a stats system for both weapons and equipment, the latter of which directly affects the player's endurance and performance, quests, NPC's to interact with, and a fully dynamic open world that is constantly alive.

The harsh environment, dubbed The Zone"

reviewText: The start of the bleak ex-bloc survival shooter. STALKER SoC is an example of a systems-heavy open world FPS, that does an amazing job of demonstrating the broader potential within the genre. The mix of exploration, survival, hostile environment, and warring factions, makes for a much more compelling setting than any standard military or tactical shooter. The story of SoC is particularly strong, despite leaning on an amnesiac opening, and with multiple endings, you'll at least want to keep a few save files on hand. Travel and exploration are both dangerous and rewarding. Managing your inventory is a challenge, requiring mastery in itself. If you go into Stalker expecting to be an RPG-style pack mule, you'll be disappointed. reviewText: Don't mind hour count. Had this as a physical copy, in the first place, way before Steam.\nThis game is the pinnacle of post apocalyptic games. Pure survival. Constantly low ammo, low medicines, broken armour and weapons, and a ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• ton of spooky enemies everywhere. You can also perish for not eating or drinking, not to mention radiation. And not to mention gravitational/eletromagnetic anomalies you'll stumble into while running for your life, or searching for radioactive artifacts, that will either way kill you hopelessly. Everytime you leave your safe haven to start a quest, it feels like a true adventure... and you're never sure you'll be back in one piece on the first try. Most of the time, you won't. reviewText:
Talk about a game with immersion - Having played S.T.A.L.K.E.R. SOC on retail disk countless times and then regretably selling it, I jumped at the chance to pick up the Steam version cheap on Ebay.

You play as the Marked One" and your travels will take you across the vast wasteland of the Zone near the Chernobyl NCP in the Ukraine.  This open ended blended RPG FPS will keep you plenty occupied with enough playtime to log countless hours.  There are a number of quests and side missions to partake in or just venture the Zone and kill mutants and search for artifiacts if you please - this i what I do sometimes to kill time and play around in the world.. just to enjoy its menacing atmosphere.

The immersion and atmosphere is deliciuosly unique and the Stalker series is my fav regarding a creepy feeling.  I use the "Complete" mod available at artistpavel.com and it intensifies the atmosFEAR and graphics as well as does a complete overhaul of the game for a more stable experience.  Real time weather and day/night cycles are a treat to behold.  Sound and Music is great with eerie/spooky ambience throughout
date: gun effects are realistic.\n\nThe graphics look stunning for portraying the grislt world of the zone which is a treacherous
recommended: darkly beautiful radioactive wasteland.  For as big as the game is the world looks fantastic and considering its a few years old.\n\nThis is a hard game (my opionion) and I think is designed toward a more die hard PC player - it is not run and gun - you will die plenty.  The A.I. is tuff and smart - dodge and cover is there motto.   The first time you encounter a controller watch out - one of my favorite enemies ever.  Nearly half my friends list already has this gem
hoursPlayed: so they know a great game when they see it.\n\nGood hunting Stalker.  ‚úîRecommended"

To sum up, it a game which you will love if you enjoy a challange, a time sink, amazing enviroments and the genre itself.

reviewText:
Simply put STALKER is an atmospheric open-world first-person-shooter.
As a larger whole it's also the finest PC gaming has to offer: it challenges you and doesn't hold your hand. It 's graphically impressive, yet can be scaled down to work on weaker machines. It's poorly executed at parts but the very ideas behind it were so ambitious that you have to like it just for trying. And it has a highly moddable and customizable structure.

I most definitely recommend this to anyone interested in open-world shooting or post-apocalyptic atmosphere. Invest time looking into and installing mods to really get your moneys worth.

reviewText: Mutant mayhem\n\nThe STALKER games have a reputation for being tough, and it‚Äôs well-deserved -- this is probably the most challenging single-player game I‚Äôve played. Both the open world and the AI are very unforgiving. There are constant dangers not just from the wide variety of enemies but also from high levels of radiation and strange spatial anomalies. The Zone is a large place and during the course of the game you get to visit a diverse range of environments and encounter many weird malevolent forces. The combat is always demanding and requires a good deal of strategic thinking given that you have to deal with other health-depleting factors at the same time. The story, although it does suffer from the usual lack of focus as a result of non-linear gameplay and some uninspiring side quests, is still reasonably strong and engaging. Graphically it‚Äôs quite impressive, although I should point out that I installed the STALKER Complete 2009 mod from the get-go, which (as I understand it) improves on the vanilla game in this area. It‚Äôs true that there are some annoying bugs, but they didn‚Äôt dampen my enjoyment of the game too much. And even though the weapons and armour deteriorate (a feature I‚Äôm not overly fond of) the speed with which this occurs is more realistic than in many RPGs so it didn‚Äôt bug me too much. Overall the game scores very highly for its outstanding atmosphere, which is one of the most engrossing, and idiosyncratic, that I‚Äôve encountered. Highly recommended. 4/5

reviewText: STALKER is a little slow-paced for an FPS, but it does a great job of conveying the bleak and dangerous nature of the Zone. It raises some interesting questions and points about how people perceive a catastrophic event - to most it's a tragedy, but to some it's an opportunity. One thing I would have liked to be explored is how the player character reacts to waking up with no memories and with his only direction being to kill a man. Would he do so unquestioningly, or would he resist? But that's a question for another time. Overall, STALKER is an excellently atmospheric open-world game where the realism augments the feel instead of getting in the way.\n\nFull review here: http://postlaunch.blogspot.ca/2012/07/stalker-shadow-of-chernobyl.html

reviewText:
I absolutely adore this game. For whatever reason it was one of my earliest Steam purchases, and really set a precedent for me. I'm probably one of the few people left that plays this game without mods/vanilla, and I'm always hesitant to install them. This game was my Dark Souls many years earlier. It is brutal and unforgiving and really takes an understanding of what is happening around you so that you can eventually feel like you are actually a powerful force in the world you inhabit and deserve to be as such. Hauntingly beatiful and deathly terrifying, I'd recommend this game to anyone who enjoys difficult atmospheric shooters (think early Metro 2033/Last Light with more outdoors settings). It has been a long time since I've had to learn and pay attention as much in a game as in this one, and I'll forever revel in it as it holds a special place in my heart. The following games advance in different directions but still afford notice, I've only played its prequel and not the sequel so I can't make particular recommendations there.

If you like what you've heard here, and want to pick up an extremely interesting game that it would be hard to spend more than $20 on, heed my advice and go for it

8/10

For first playthough, either Vanilla or Complete. This is the standard experience. Mandatory for everyone.

For second playthough, either LURK or Autumn Aurora. Adds content, like weapons and armors.

For third playthough, Oblivion Lost or ELITE mod. Adds moar content, like vehicles, anomalies, and artifacts, and humour.

For fourth playthough, Priboi story or STALKERSOUP. Adds the most content like maps, main stories, and everything else.

reviewText:
First and foremost, because I would like to point this out first, because most of the people reading this probably will not want to read the whole massive explanation as to why I like this game. So to summarize, first, this game is an incredibly excellent game that suffers from some bugs and semi-regular crashes, but you can get unoffical patches and mods that help fix that a little bit. I gotta point out though, this game can potentially be balls-to-the-wall hard. So... Expect to play this game methodically, and not rushing through Call of Duty style hoping you won't get hosed down will bullets or surrounded by mutants and mauled to death. Because, spoiler alert, you will. And now, on to the big explanation!

S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Shadow of Chernobyl is a game ahead of its time. Running off of a system where you need to conserve bullets, monitor your weapons' and armor's conditions, and be very conservative with materials. All of this is mostly thanks to the weight system. In most games that incorporate a weight system, like Elder Scrolls titles and Fallout games, ammunition (Usually) weighs nothing. Not in S.T.A.L.K.E.R., no, in S.T.A.L.K.E.R., bullets weigh a devent amount. So this brings an interesting system to the fore. In most games, I would have main firearms, one as my preferred gun, and the other as my backup, and load up on ammo for both of those. You can do that in S.T.A.L.K.E.R., but it's not optimal. Rather, you should probably just load up on ammo for your main weapons (Pistol and assault weapon), otherwise you'll be over-encumbered.
S.T.A.L.K.E.R. also has a bleeding system. If you get shot in a non-vital spot, you bleed, and you should bandage up or you're gonna slowly bleed out. If it's a lesser wound, you don't need to worry about it, it won't bleed much. It's color coded, if it's red, you'll bleed out if you don't treat it, if it's green, it'll most likely heal in a moment or two. If it's yellow, it'll heal, it will just take a while, and you're probably better off bandaging it. This is the first game (Regarding it's time of release, in 2007) that I have seen a game make the bleeding system pertain to enemy AI as well. You hit and enemy with a few shots to the chest, he'll probably either die in a few moments, or curl up on the ground and eventually die like that. It's still very impressive.
Everything about the weapons, armor, and gameplay, generally is extremely impressive. But that doesn't mean I don't have my gripes with the game. There are a few problems:
A: this game can be buggy as ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•. F6 oddly is the default quick save button. I set it to F5, becuase that's what it is in most games. That button is your friend. Use it a lot.
B: I feel that a lot of the mutants take waaaaaaaay too mant rounds to put down. Unless you manage to hit them in the head, which is hard. Hell, even the blind dogs take like, at least a clip and a half from my Vintar BC to drop if I don't hit them in theh ead. There's a point where it starts to feel ridiculous, considering that this game pretty much forces you to ration off your ammo supplies.
C: This game has an INSANE difficulty jump at the end of the game. It would be fine, if it didn't break all the rules that this game makes you obey. It forces you to move fast, and to act fast, while not dying. Up until that point, you essentially have to take everything slow and planned out. This ending just... It threw me off.
---- Quick save is your friend. Remember this. ----

Anyway, altogether, this game is awesome. There's a whole lot to do in it, between the warring factions, Duty and Freedom, and the side missions, there's a surprising lot to do. I would strongly suggest picking this game up if you haven't yet, and pick upt the STALKER: Complete mod for Shadow of Chernobyl. Makes it look a lot better, and tends to fix a lot of the issues the game has.

reviewText: S.T.A.L.K.E.R remains to be the only game that I play which has FPS combat, for a multitude of reasons. S.T.A.L.K.E.R: Shadow of Chernobyl is an RPG set in the post-apocalyptic grounds of radiation-filled Chernobyl, where S.T.A.L.K.E.R's roam and reign in this wild west of mutants and Russians in gas masks. This oldie remains captivating to me because of this one, simple thing: It was crafted with care. Hell, the designers went INTO CHERNOBYL and modeled parts of the game after what they saw.\n\nShadow of Chernobyl is a game built on atmosphere. Ho-lee ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•, atmosphere is extremely present. From the way the lighting is done, to the wind effects, to the echoes of mutated animals crying out in the fields, to the eerie trance of quiet music beneath the whoosh of wind blowing by you as you trek through a field, bleeding and tired from an encounter... It really feels like what the developpers intended, which is that you're struggling to survive in Chernobyl with what you can find. Without adding legitimate horror aspects
date:
S.T.A.L.K.E.R developped a tinge of scariness with the excessive ammount of eerie that drives home the point it was going for.

The combat engine is relatively simplistic, but it's satisfying. The damage frame makes cover actually necessary to outlast a longer fight, therefore making the lean function actually useful. The noise and visibility system added to the game also gives you the choice to go in stealthily or half-cocked, and also makes it that much more realistic; other people can HEAR YOU SNEAKING if you're sloppy, and wandering around with a flashlight will give away your position to anything that wants to kill you. Combine this system with angry russians, a gas mask, and some creepy torn up towns, and you've got S.T.A.L.K.E.R.

Honestly, I'd pick this over Fallout any day of the week. I'd recommend this game to ANYONE.

reviewText: STALKER: Shadow of Chernobyl was one of those games where if you didn't know what it was about originally, you would have passed on it. reviewText: Mutant mayhem\n\nThe STALKER games have a reputation for being tough, and it‚Äôs well-deserved -- this is probably the most challenging single-player game I‚Äôve played. Both the open world and the AI are very unforgiving. There are constant dangers not just from the wide variety of enemies but also from high levels of radiation and strange spatial anomalies. The Zone is a large place and during the course of the game you get to visit a diverse range of environments and encounter many weird malevolent forces. The combat is always demanding and requires a good deal of strategic thinking given that you have to deal with other health-depleting factors at the same time. The story, although it does suffer from the usual lack of focus as a result of non-linear gameplay and some uninspiring side quests, is still reasonably strong and engaging. Graphically it‚Äôs quite impressive, although I should point out that I installed the STALKER Complete 2009 mod from the get-go, which (as I understand it) improves on the vanilla game in this area. It‚Äôs true that there are some annoying bugs, but they didn‚Äôt dampen my enjoyment of the game too much. And even though the weapons and armour deteriorate (a feature I‚Äôm not overly fond of) the speed with which this occurs is more realistic than in many RPGs so it didn‚Äôt bug me too much. Overall the game scores very highly for its outstanding atmosphere, which is one of the most engrossing, and idiosyncratic, that I‚Äôve encountered. Highly recommended. 4/5

reviewText: Stalker may be the crown-jewel of Slavic post-apocalyptic games, surpassing even Metro 2033. With beautiful environments, a haunting ambient soundtrack, and vicious monsters, Stalker sets a dark tone for this survival-horror shooter. However, you will find that, unlike Metro 2033, humans play as great as threat as the monsters, perhaps even more so depending on how you play. With dozens of weapons, quests, and characters, you will be well prepared to discover all of Chernobyl's secrets. What is more, compared to Western post-apocalyptic games such as Fallout, Stalker possesses a much deeper and more intense story, especially towards the end, when the truth is revealed. Normally I would never recommend mods for a game, but in this case, I believe that Stalker Complete is well worth it, removing/fixing multiple glitches, and thus contributing to a smoother game. Overall, despite the savage nature of the environment, one cannot help but be impressed with how beautifully the developers strung together the story and characters. Overall Score: 10/10

reviewText:
STALKER: Shadow of Chernobyl is, perhaps, one of the greatest video games I've ever played. Complete with role playing elements, fantastic action, extreme difficulty and terrifying moments, the game delivers in every way.

GRAPHICS:
First off all, I would highly suggest everyone download the STALKER Complete 2009 Mod on www.moddb.com, as it increases visuals and gameplay performance tenfold and makes the dated game look on par to Crysis. Without the mod, however, colors are bland, facial expressions are dull, shading is downright awful, and textures are muddy. It's not terrible, but I would highly suggest the mod be installed if your PC can handle it.

GAMEPLAY:
This is the iffy part of the game. While the controls aren't particularly difficult to comprehend, some movements feel clunky. Also, without the mod installed (let's face it, the mod improved everything), guns will jam frequently and bullets will go off course at point blank range. This is most of the time a reoccuring glitch, but is no less annoying. With the mod installed, you can have more role playing options available - joining groups and factions, repairing weapons and armor, and even getting more weapons and equipment not available in the original game, and the fact that this mod is free and easy to install just makes it better. However, the gameplay isn't perfect even with the installed mod. Enemies can shoot you through walls, the easiest difficulty is unbelieveably brutal to new players as enemies can kill you in just a few rifle shots or a few melee hits (if it's a mutant). The human AI isn't very smart, but hell they can kill easily. The truly impressive enemies are the mutants. Ranging from sickeningly deformed hounds to massive monstrosities that will haunt your nightmares for days, each mutant comes with its own abilities, attacks, and frightening appearances, making this just as much a survival horror experience as an RPG/Shooter. Glitches aside, the gameplay (though made better with the mod) is fun, easy to learn, and solid.

STORY:
This is where the game truly shines. The story is perhaps one of the most original that I've seen in any game in the past decade. You are a man known only as the 'Marked One,' due to the tatoo on your arm. You have no idea who you really are, what you're doing, or why you're in Chernobyl. All you know is that written on your PDA are the words: KILL THE STRELOK." From there
date: you must fight through the horrors of the nuclear wasteland in the heart of Ukraine
recommended: uncovering the secrets of your past and the dark horrors that the government have tried so hard to cover up. The story is interactive
voteText:

reviewText: This is the single most terrifying game I have ever played, and one of the most striking I have ever experienced. The sense of isolation, of total fear, is unmatched by anything except perhaps if you played System Shock as a child. A gun will keep you alive, but it cannot defend you from the anomalies, the radiation, the hunger. It cannot penetrate the darkness for you. It cannot be a friend, a confidant, or an ally. All you have is yourself, and man has made his own personal hell in the Zone. Coupled with mods to alleviate the worst of the bugs (and what game of ambition and vision has been anything but buggy?), I rate this as one of the most compelling experiences I've ever had in gaming memory, even six years after its release.

reviewText: This is probably my favorite game of all time. The game has an amazing story. If you enjoy Russian/Ukrainian science fiction mixed with urban legend wrapped up in a big, beautiful plot twist bow, then this is the game for you. Although the story may feel patchy at times, I enjoyed it the whole way through. There are about 7 different endings, two of them being very special. This game effectively incorporates horror, action, and survival tactics into one large environment. This is a very immersive game; the audio is spectacular, the lighting system is top notch, the enemies are terrifying, and the combat system is well put together and feels good. There are plenty of enjoyable mods for this game which does increase the replay value. If you get this game, I highly suggest playing on the hardest difficulty. The game will be much more enjoyable. I never got into the faction system very much, but if you enjoy factions then it's a feature of the game. I did not experience very many bugs or glitches while playing this game, yet it seems that others have had a lot of difficulties with bugs and glitches. I believe the bugs and glitches in this game are hit or miss. Overall, this is a well made game with a superb story and I would suggest it to anyone who enjoys RPG-FPS style games.

reviewText: Stalker may be the crown-jewel of Slavic post-apocalyptic games, surpassing even Metro 2033. With beautiful environments, a haunting ambient soundtrack, and vicious monsters, Stalker sets a dark tone for this survival-horror shooter. However, you will find that, unlike Metro 2033, humans play as great as threat as the monsters, perhaps even more so depending on how you play. With dozens of weapons, quests, and characters, you will be well prepared to discover all of Chernobyl's secrets. What is more, compared to Western post-apocalyptic games such as Fallout, Stalker possesses a much deeper and more intense story, especially towards the end, when the truth is revealed. Normally I would never recommend mods for a game, but in this case, I believe that Stalker Complete is well worth it, removing/fixing multiple glitches, and thus contributing to a smoother game. Overall, despite the savage nature of the environment, one cannot help but be impressed with how beautifully the developers strung together the story and characters. Overall Score: 10/10

reviewText:
NOTICE: This review is on the original (vanilla) version of S.T.A.L.K.E.R. which excludes all mods.
==================

Editorial Notes: One of by far the best FPS/RPG games I've ever own, was at first a little hesitant about this style. It has very odd controls and the AI is a laughable joke at easy settings but get incredibly difficult in harder/master difficulty (learn to duck and run when they reload). I'll be straight honest it is by far one of my favorite games to play when you have time to kill, just the missions alone can spend roughly 10+ hours if you really go above and beyond the beaten path and investigate nearly everything possible. A few Easter eggs can be found which I thought was rather clever but more importantly is the factions that act as you biggest pain the butt but the source of your jobs as a murderous psychopath. Each time I replay my game I try to use a different weapon that I rarely use, or a subset of weapons that I deemed unworthy to best myself and train in the hardest way possible (i.e. take a pistol or knife and kill a: snork, bloodsucker, any military officer) and even getting semi-creative with the use of surroundings.

I will admit that the AI is very old and outdated meaning that they go by the line-of-sight controls. If they see an enemy they'll attack via line-of-sight and will gain a foothold by literally going straight even if that means going into a: fireplace, anomaly, or direct line of friendly fire (which in return get mad at you). AI also have two settings for accuracy, either they trained in the clone troopers training base or became solid-snake that trained with Agent 47's agency which ultimately depends on the difficulty you have it set to. Word of advice, rely solely on F6 && F7 your two newly formed friends of the trade.

Pros:
+ Fun and interesting gameplay that stands against older games

+ Can be rather challenging even during a 'weapon-free' zone; certain missions can leave you with an complex scenario where you can either go in guns blazing like Rambo or be like Sam Fisher and sneak your way in.

+ Able to 'peak' around corners for some very unique firefights, AI can also assist in firefights (just watch for friendly-fire).

+ Certain areas/zones have eerie soundtracks that even to this creation of this review, has a creepy factor that makes you watch your back.

+ Open world; once you have certain missions completed or can pay off the right people.

+ Different factions can ultimately change the gameplay; each having their own perks respectfully. (Duty = weapons, Freedom = Armor, STALKER = 'Monay Monay Monay....who needed Monay?')

+ Semi-stealth; there is a stealth factor to the game as in if its dark enough enemies will have a harder time detecting you while you sneak. Whereas if you were to walk into a bush everyone including their mother will hear you thus alerting them to your presence. [Silence weapons are silent, if you get a kill it will be a silent unless they had line-of-sight on that target].


Cons:
- AI; as said before they will follow the path of the least resistance, even if that means walking into a anomaly or your line of fire. Some AI are even clueless as to where to go sometimes and will watch your movement until nearly everyone is dead in that area or they'll aimbot the next available unit even if its behind walls.

- Controls; some of the controls are a little wonky. To access your PDA, press P. To check status of active task, press TAB. To go nearly prone, press CTRL + Shift (whilst using WASD and peaking corners). Some of the motions are a little clumsy, especially when getting shot at and needing to heal but fear that the moment you let go of the mouse you will literally run smack-dab into a bandit.

- Difficulty; Can be easy as pie one minute then the next you are in the middle of one heck of a firefight with no clear visual of where that sniper is and BAM" you see the text "You Are Dead" in harder settings. The harder you go the more accurate the enemy becomes
date: thus meaning that AK's can quite literally kill you in 2-3 hits even with a SEVA/Exoskeleton suit.\n\n- Buggy/Glitchy; Like most games there are bugs
recommended:
but this game has quite a number of them (most are actually funny to see and do not really hinder the game performance). Situations such as side-missions can be tedious especially when you have to attack a group of military outside of Agroprom Research Institute by the zone load area and one of the military officers goes way behind the loading zone thus you cannot kill them but they can attack you. Certain areas have a weird NPC spawn area (wild territories) where friends or foe can literally spawn above you. Some of the more funnier glitches is using an explosive barrel near NPC's and watch them run into the fireplace and die.

- Loading Areas; certain areas will have a 'loading' area to render the next part of the game. This can be very annoying when being chased and you 'load' into the next area but since you ran before the load you will waste your entire stamina and now your character cannot run away from what was hunting you down (i.e. running from the dogs in the bar area) You can theoretically bypass a few of them by going into a different part of the world but does not work for all.

- Stealth; Like I said before there is a stealth factor but its very odd. You have to get a kill with a silent weapon (guns with silencer or a knife) whist being undetected or seen from an enemy. You have a visual bar that will show if you've been seen but it doesn't work part of the time
hoursPlayed:
long distance firefights are the way to go if stealth is the objective.

==================
Conclusion: I really love this game with a passion! Even though that it was outdated and old

It's a fun game to have if you like FPS/RPG games and is by far one game that I love to use with mods (L.U.R.K. and the complete pack are fun to use). The replay ability is unheard of because you can replay the game but different NPC's will be used in different areas so where enemies might be wont spawn there till later or earlier in game

reviewText:
This game is awesome!! It is like a mature, more serious version of Fallout (though admittedly not as intricate, it's not really an RPG at all). The biggest point in this games favour is the immersion. After an hour I really got wrapped up in the whole world here. It really makes you feel like a loner in a desolate land where everyone is struggling by against bizarre and mysterious forces. Even little things like... hearing the distant cries of animals, the sounds of gun fights somewhere far off, a group of survivors just sitting around the campfire, chatting and playing guitar. It really adds to the immersion!

The missions are somewhat varied. You don't feel bored really. Some missions (in the labs) are really some of the best ever, giving a feeling of survival horror or like the Shalebridge Crade from Thief 3. The locations are all memorable and no two are comparable. The gun play is decent enough though you can get killed pretty easily so this requires much more caution. There's some good chances to customize your load out (though not to Fallout levels).

As for negatives... it could use a fast travel system like Skyrim. The map is huge and some missions mean travelling one side to the other regularly. Also, in a game where immersion is so evident I'd have expected to do more reading/listening to reports and notes left by other survivors. Some people hate that but I think in this game, if well done, really would've added to it.

NOTE: there is also a big modding community for this game. Search for the Stalker Complete series. There is a Complete" mod for each Stalker game. I am currently playing the vanilla version and it plays fine but have a look at the mod.

reviewText:
This is by far my favourite game of all time. I must of bought the game in 2009. I remember the first time playing it, I almost gave up on it as i thought I would not like it. Within an hour or starting I was completely hooked and couldn't pry myself away from the screen.

The storyline,visuals, sound and most importantly atmosphere is like no other game I have encountered, and still hasnt been surpassed to this day. It is scary enough to keep you on the edge of your seat and heart racing, but never makes you feel completely helpless like all the survival horror games. It will most likely leave you clinging onto your mouse and keyboard for dear life.

The freedom this game gives is also very rewarding. I am not a fan of linear shooters such as metro 2033, so if you like a bit of exploring this is the game for you.

reviewText:
Strongly recommended.

I first bought the game media DVD days after it was relased and reached my region... however, due to various reasons, I could not play it until now... those reasons were mainly language barrier (not native English, or good English at that time), so I could not understand much of the game back then... also my first encounter of the bloodsucker :D it made me jump on my seat... (I'll never forget that moment :D), so I thought: this is not the right time to play this game...

I kept it in the shelve collecting dust, ignoring it, and I thought I wasted my money on it...

Now, I got it on steam, and finally I could understand English well, so I thought, why not give it a try and see what is this game really is?

I installed the 3 games, and started with SoC 2 weeks ago, and I just finished it...

This game is now my number one game and I loved every single moment of it while I was playing... I lived with the main character through every single corner and place of it, and I will not forget my time playing this game...

I will replay it, and I will make different choices through the game, again and again... I will not get bored of it I'm sure of this...

This game has everything, RPG (of course), action, horror, mysteries, stealth and sneaking, and even some drama...

This series (the 3 games Shadow of Chernobyl, Clear Sky, and Call of Pripyat), made me feel really sad for that there will be no STALKER II of it... and I really hope that a day will come and I see this got a II" after its name...

I definately recommend this to every single gamer who want adventure and all types of game play mixed in 1 game...
This should get more hype and more known over some "big" titles out there."

reviewText:
Lets get some things out of the way
-this game is not a twich shooter its gunplay is more similar to arma than CoD (which may be a dealbreaker for some)
-you are slow and lumbering plus the lack of fast travel makes going back and forth between quests somewhat boring and monotonous
-without spoiling anything the ending came out of nowhere (I was halfway expecting to be pulled back into the game after the credits)
-there is no skills progression and base level weapons are still effective at end game if used properly
-there are odd difficulty spikes when the rng nature of openents weapons and equipment rolls against you
-game is not fully voiced in english (understandable given its Ukrainian developers
-enemy AI has dificulty tracking moving targets (you can really hit them while running so its not game breaking)
-you will die... alot (F6 quicksave F7 load last save)

with those points out of the way I would like to say why I recomend this game
-the skill based gunplay feels intuitive and fun
-game is dufficult and unforgiving but fair
-game builds up tension like nothing youve ever seen due to its fantastic lighting and sound design
-I like to think of myself as being hard to scare but this game manages to
-HEADSOTS ARE INSAKILL (for you and enemy keep that in mind when your questioning why you got oneshoted)
-interesting faction and npc relationship system with every npc in game (shoot out a bandits legs but let him live and that same guy might save you in the future unless he gets eaten by wild dogs)
-game will let you fail quests (essential ones will have to be completed some other way(branching?))
-randomized unique weapons (you will more then likely main a autosniper that uses pistol ammo if you find one like I did(didnt make sense but I rolled with it))
-this game will make you make tough decisions (spent 15 mins deciding weither i needed an rpg with one shot or my ammo for my main weapon(dont you ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing judge me!!!))

reviewText:
A PC classic. The game has the most tense, dreadful,  and eerie atmosphere of any game I've ever played. It's not aging well graphically however, and the vanilla version still has a ton of bugs. That said, it's a huge amount of fun once you get into it and soak up the Zone's own little world of monsters and anamolies, but it requires patience, this is not an easy game and can be very frustrating. It's a very well made shooter and the story (while confusing at times) is worth getting into to learn more about the Zone and the game's incredible lore. There are a TON of mods out there for this game that can add things like graphical updates to complete overhauls of everything including the story.

I HIGHLY recommend getting into the regular version first to play it as it was made to be then, if you ever want to play it again, mod it for a new experience.

With all of that said, this is easily one of the greatest PC games ever made and is still incredibly fun 9 years on. If you want a challenge and a world filled with wonder and fear, this is worth your time.

Good hunting STALKER.

reviewText: Stalker may be the crown-jewel of Slavic post-apocalyptic games, surpassing even Metro 2033. With beautiful environments, a haunting ambient soundtrack, and vicious monsters, Stalker sets a dark tone for this survival-horror shooter. However, you will find that, unlike Metro 2033, humans play as great as threat as the monsters, perhaps even more so depending on how you play. With dozens of weapons, quests, and characters, you will be well prepared to discover all of Chernobyl's secrets. What is more, compared to Western post-apocalyptic games such as Fallout, Stalker possesses a much deeper and more intense story, especially towards the end, when the truth is revealed. Normally I would never recommend mods for a game, but in this case, I believe that Stalker Complete is well worth it, removing/fixing multiple glitches, and thus contributing to a smoother game. Overall, despite the savage nature of the environment, one cannot help but be impressed with how beautifully the developers strung together the story and characters. Overall Score: 10/10

reviewText:
1st person, open world, apocalyptic action shooter with RPG, fiction and horror elements. It's the 2nd game in timeline, following soon after the events of S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Clear Sky. This is the original S.T.A.L.K.E.R. and first game in the series, about zone that surrounds 30km around destroyed nuclear power plant. Aftermath of tragedy at Chernobyl power plant (Ukraine USSR) that took place in 1986, when one of nuclear reactors in Chernobyl nuclear power plant exploded, releasing big quantities of radiation and contaminating large area around the plant and nearby town of Pripyat. Developers took this true and gruesome story, added fiction and horror elements from the S.T.A.L.K.E.R. books, to make a unique and atmospheric 1st person action shooter experience.

Story takes place long after the events of 1986, now it's 2012 and zone around Chernobyl is nothing like it was before. In year 2006, there was 2nd reactor explosion (fiction) that expanded the zone and sent waves of energy and radiation outwards, killing every living being in the area. Only military personal and scientists were allowed to enter the zone. Even though military closed all the entrances and fenced down 30km area around the power plant, despite the dangers people started to venture inside the zone, exploring unknown areas, discovering new anomalies, artifacts and creatures within. Later those brave yet outlaw individuals were called Stalkers.

Though your story in beginning of the game is unclear, because you are suffering from some sort of amnesia, you must uncover the events that took place before you awoke on Sidorovich's table, with strange tattoo on your arm and single objective in your Personal digital assistant" (PDA)

reviewText: A one of a kind horror/shooter with a compelling plot, fantastic array of weapons and equipment, an immersive world, and an interesting array of factions and personalities. I recommend this particularly to fans of Metro 2033/Last Light as a more challenging and atmospheric alternative, despite being a good few years old, the game has aged well and (as far as I have experienced.) Runs smoothly; it contains a very nice inventory system also. The plot follows a Russian 'S.T.A.L.K.E.R' who has come to the zone to scavenge for artifacts after a fictional second explosion at the Chernobyl reactor, but suffers amnesia. The rest picks up from there. Despite the stellar experience, I do find the game is plagued by steep difficulty curves, an unusable stealth mechanic (the HUD has a sound metre but as far as I know, stealth isn't possible unless the enemy is sleeping.) And I found a lot of the areas looking a little too similar to one another, however, this doesn't tarnish this true gem of modern times.\n\n10/10 Would cheeki breeki again.
